Author: jon.forbord
Content: based on Linux real time core, so as real time as any other Linux based modern PLC, surely cycle times in sub-millisecond is possible, supports EtherCAT amongst others, Python, C, C++ and more..

Author: trentc
Content: Agreed, in theory...but what is it in practice? can we get sub ms updates? and can we process and execute our code in that timeframe? I know not all code and data will be realtime...but I'm wondering what is possible and reasonable to expect, if one were to build their machines using this as their primary controls platform for the future.

Author: trentc
Content: Our Omron controllers run on a linux realtime os, and can get down to 125us task time as well as EtherCAT updates, however that update rate will be limited by the hardware on the network. Honestly i'm not even looking for that fast....I just don't want to be stuck with 20ms....I want 1ms possible.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: EtherCAT + ctrlx, would easily manage 1ms if that‚Äôs what you‚Äôre looking for.. their previous generation controllers did 1ms cyclic tasks and data exchange.

Author: trentc
Content:
Thanks for the reassurance, I've just seen so many platforms come out focused on industry 4.0 and edge capabilities that you end up compromising in performance for controls. 
I know that most applications today require some edge connectivity solution, but I'm looking into the future, when we no longer need that edge "gateway"....and the controls platform works natively in our architecture.

Author: jonnywright4
Content:
OK we've collated @trentc - 4.0 Hero LLC 's Questions:-
Can the ctrlX platform be managed completely remotely? 
**Yes there is a device management in place which allows security updates, software updates, backup and restore and remote connection.

How real time is the realtime IO? Is there support for CAN or serial based protocols like profibus, devicenet, CANopen ? 
*Realtime IO depands on the EtherCAT fieldbus cycle time, it's 1 ms for ctrlX CORE X3 and with the faster ctrlX CORE X7 even faster. There is a support of Profinet. CAN is currently only supported via CANope USB adapter or via EtherCAT CoE profile.

Can we import our own Python libraries? 
*Yes, you will need to compile them within your own snap container (container format of the platform).

How does it perform in AI/ML heavy applications? 
*ctrlX CORE X3 (ARM-based) can execute models, ctrlX CORE X7 (Intel i7 based) can calculate more AI stuff. But there is an additional Hailo-based accelator module possible for AI calculations.

Can we run ctrlX os on our own hardware?
*It is planned to run ctrlX OS on third party hardware. Currently Bosch Rexroth is in a evaluation phase with several device manufacturers.

Can we run a small database on the core?
*Yes, there is the InfluxDB app available. Check this how-to:
IIoT: Use ctrlX CORE as a monitoring platform usin... (boschrexroth.com)
https://developer.community.boschrexroth.com/t5/Store-and-How-to/IIoT-Use-ctrlX-CORE-as-a-monitoring-platform-using-InfluxDB-and/ba-p/65882 

What about deploying changes, updates, taking backups at scale? 
*this is possible via the fleet management ctrlX Device Portal

Author: trentc
Content:
From birds eye view, I agree that it could sound like the "flavor of the month" for IIOT.
But digging in and comparing the details, I disagree...

Most of the other solutions don't make it easier to make the tools function together as if they are one, and most times it's hard to tell that they are all running on the same platform. The primary benefit of many is that you can run it on the same hardware, but you still have to integrate as if they were completely separate and not intended to work together.
They very well could be running on separate systems, its not much different to integrate either way on these solutions.

The way it is all packaged to be more uniform instead of acting like each piece is totally separate is a differentiator. It starts as a blank slate with only platform configuration, then you go to the store to install apps like you would your smartphone. The functions, features, configuration and programming provided by the apps are all brought into a common web UI.  Managed, deployed, backed up, and restored as one solution.
 
The combination of Realtime IO and event based data on a common data layer makes it a powerful combination of controls, data management, and connectivity. Every app can have access to this data layer, for example there are Node-red nodes to publish/subscribe to data here, as well as in the codesys based "engineering" programming IDE the code can access realtime IO, or the event based data layer. This is also true for the IDE app that lets you program in blockly, python, javascript.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: It did feel a little "Siemens-esque" to me.  WDYT?

Author: trentc
Content:
Lets say I wanted to integrate a traditional PLC, Node-Red, and Python....
1. Install IPC, install necessary OS, node-red, and python dependancies
      Where do I get all this stuff and how to I install it?
2. What is the physical PLC interface? Serial, ethernet? what protocols?
3. Identify how to read/write data from the PLC with Node-Red....
      Can I find a node that will do this?
      How to use the node and Does the node even work?
4. oh wait I gotta do that with python too!
      Which libraries do I need to do this?
      How to use the library, and does it even work?
5. Ok now I have everything to read data into my node-red and python....
6. Wait, now I want data from python in node-red....
7. Figure out combination of nodes and libraries that allows python and node red data exchange 
8. Ok, now I can develop
9. Boy, I hope no-one asks me how this works, or tries to figure it out after me.....hehe


With the unified platform like ctrlX...
1. Install ctrlX core and get it connected to the internet.
2. Install from the app store, PLC, node-red, python RT, and IDE
3. Now I'm ready to develop.
4. All necessary integration between apps is done through already included libraries
5. All apps are managed centrally in a common UI, able to see apps installed, applications that are running and even a data layer explorer to see the data on the shared data bus.

The time and effort it takes to get actually developing is so much shorter...and ability to manage it by others is no comparison.

Other implementations are between these 2, like Opto22, and a step closer is PLCNext.

Author: trentc
Content:
Thanks for putting in the effort to reply to each of my questions.
- The EtherCAT performance sounds like it meets my expectations and beyond.
- I'd imagine we can solve the serial and can protocol connectivity with some combination of the tools/apps available, its a matter of the physical interface.
- It would be nice if I could just include my own python libraries in the IDE app instead of having to create my own container, but good to know there is a solution.
- I'm glad to see an AI acceleration module, as I believe AI/ML at the edge/on machine is increasing in demand.
- I see I can run ctrlX virtual for development, so maybe I don't need to run on my own hardware.
- Thats awesome the power of apps brings InfluxDB....I am wondering about an SQL DB though...only for lightweight local storage.
- Fleet management sounds good too

But I don't believe Rexroth should build it in, as they have just created a controls platform for developers to build their own solution. The driving logic behind the state is still process/machine specific, even if there are general rules that can be followed the logic and variable conditions may differ. And it's up to the leadership in this community to guide them to include it.

Author: rickbullotta
Content:
Rockwell et al are adding edge container support (partnered with Zededa), which makes it trivial to add something "app-store-ish".  I think this will be foundational technology that we come to expect soon.

I also do not think it is usually a good idea to run "alien" workloads on the same controller as things like motion control or time sensitive control or safety logic.  It's cheap insurance to add another device, even if on the same high speed backplane, to perform those adjacent functions.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: I agree. I like the Linux/Unix philosophy of do one thing but do it well, but make it easy to combine to do what you want (i.e. shell scripts).  Things like grep, sed, awk, + regex can all be combined to do very advanced and automated things.

Author: brianpribe
Content: I think docker on a PLC would be a phenomenal addition. The fact that they have safety and motion PLCs already sold me (minimum viable product)

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Docker does not provide adequate isolation IMO. I don't want it "on" the PLC, and I want it "on" the edge - if that's on the same backplane, fine.  But I want my controller to have some level of isolation so that 3rd party code can't crash it, introduce malware, affect performance, etc... - Docker is not the right foundation for that level of isolation and management.

Author: brianpribe
Content: ^^^That

Author: trentc
Content:
I agree that resource allocation is highly important, and the easiest way to ensure it is to have totally separate hardware. However if done correctly I don‚Äôt believe that it has to be a whole other duplicate set of resources. Pc based controls systems in one product are being executed with reliability by many. Beckhoff comes to mind, and at Omron we have an ipc that the hardware resources are allocated at the firmware level dividing the cpu cores and memory between windows and controls. Docker would have to run on the non realtime portion, if it runs on the controller, isolating it from the realtime control resources..
My preference is proven reliable open solutions with consolidated hardware and software that works well together. This minimizes the design, install, configuration and maintenance efforts of the system.

Author: trentc
Content: There‚Äôs no reason the motion engine can‚Äôt be included on the plc‚Ä¶. All of Omron NJ/NX, have motion. It comes down to resource allocation. We do however have a separate safety CPU‚Ä¶. Because it requires additional resources for the redundancy and compliance, among other reasons.

Author: daniel_hirsch
Content: I am an architect for edge computing solutions on our edge platform. I also consult our manufacturing areas on software solutions on our edge platform and implement them together with the planners. We also use the CtrlX on our machines and are currently evaluating gaps in the CtrlX platform regarding edge computing capabilities. One area is machine connectivity  and interoperability. The DeviceBridge can also be seen here, which also still lacks the Sparkplug capability (in my opinion). We stay in contact with development of both products.

Author: daniel_hirsch
Content: What are alternative standards in the machine environment for pub/sub patterns? Is interoperability even a goal worth to put effort in, or does everyone define their own models and schemas?

Author: rickbullotta
Content: OPC UA Pub/Sub, MQTT, plain old OPC DA, lots of generic pub/sub infrastructure of course.  I find Sparkplug's mixed-up payloads to be very problematic for anything but simple device <-> SCADA comms (which was its original intent).  Trying to make it do more than that will lead to a giant fail.

Author: mparris
Content:
When evaluating the products of OEMs, the quickest way I've found to separate the wheat from the chaff is to evaluate their answer to the following question:

"When I develop a device to communicate with your product, what information model do you recommend I use and why?"

Author: mparris
Content: @Daniel_H. I'm interested to hear how the product manager of the CTRLX would answer this question, given that the product advertises itself as merging IT and OT.

Author: daniel_hirsch
Content: In principle, the first step is to make the namespaces of the automation devices available as efficiently as possible on a one-to-one basis in a general infrastructure. This gives the producers a high degree of independence from consumers and use cases. This is the goal of the UNS method and parts of Sparkplug fit this very well.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Actually, it doesn‚Äôt. That‚Äôs the problem.  You can‚Äôt subscribe to individual metrics/data from a device with Sparkplug. I wish more people understood this limitation.  Also, it creates a huge degree of dependence with the way BIRTH messages currently work.  Sparkplug is overrated and severely flawed.

Author: youri.regnaud
Content: If I have a sparkplugB edge device connected to Highbyte. Do you think split SparkplugB DDATA or NDATA topic in several topic by metric with ¬´¬†breaking array¬†¬ª feature make sense?

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Absolutely.  What's the point otherwise?  It's just an opaque blob of a random number of metrics that is difficult to process upstream.  Plus you can't subscribe to or route data from  individual metrics without splitting those payloads up.  This is why I insist that Sparkplug is mostly useless beyond simple device -> SCADA/MES scenarios.  Beyond that you can hack it to sort of work, but it's not ideal.

Author: sherylmccrary
Content: Good conversation on scheduling/project management apps---Trello, Notion---for integrators and OEM developers starting here  https://discordapp.com/channels/738470295056416930/738470295056416934/1053317251668918312

Author: akoscs
Content: Is there a time series database then can be querried to goive the value of a time series at a given time AND can be set to some kind of interpolation (or just previous value retention) if at that exact timestamp there is no data, but there is data before and or after? Would be usefull if we do report by exception and feed the signal to a time series db. E.g wha was the temperature at 8:00? No data, because the temp was recorded at 7:59:59:99 and 8:00:00:01

Author: rickbullotta
Content: With millisecond or finer resolution, it's rare that you'll hit the exact timestamp ever, unless you're manipulating the timestamps prior to ingestion.  You should also consider both scenarios: one where you want interpolation, and another where you want the last recorded value prior to the requested timestamp.  In many cases, interpolation is not desirable (e.g. discrete integral states) and it often creates incorrect/fallacious data if the signal is not really continuous.  Most historians and time series DB's give you decent control over how you want data retrieved/aggregated, but if you want interpolated data in the way you hope for, it's not as easy as it might seem.  It would require two queries - one to find the reading just prior to your requested timestamp and one to get the subsequent reading.  The challenge is that you can't be certain when those readings came in, so you might need to do a broader range query and select last() or first().  It's all doable, but you might find it easiest to handle in application logic and make the necessary queries to the historian yourself.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Also, you may want to consider time-weighted averaging in your interpolation versus a simple arithmetic average.

Author: akoscs
Content:
Yes, i had to do some timestamp manipulation wich I am not proud of. but this only works with a constant pseudo sampling rate (pseudo because the timestamps are manipulated) if I want to know what what the temperature when the alarm bit is 1 and I only save the temp in a report-by-exception manner I would not know how to query it efficiently. Sure you can filter for the alarm timestamp and get the last value before that for the temp with last(). But that is just 1 instance of the alarm going of, not ‚Äûget me the temp every time the alarm went off‚Äú.

I agree interpolation is not always useful  that is why I added ‚Äûprevious value retention‚Äúas in keep the las value until the point in time specified by the new timestamp.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: That's exactly why I ended up doing it in application logic - because there are so many "exceptions" to deal with (plus I wanted to make it agnostic as to which time series data store I used).

Author: akoscs
Content: With application logic you just move the same problem to a different place. You app queries the db for the every change in the alarm time series, now you have your timestamps of interest, for each of these you will query temp values with .last(). That is not efficient, but I agree that it would work.

Author: akoscs
Content: But in essence there is no time series DB or historian which can interpolate between timestamps out of the box and interpolate the time series value or retain the newest value before the timestamp.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Plenty of them interpolate - just not in the way you are trying to accomplish.  With InfluxDB, for example, you could write some Flux code to hide all this, but it's basically the same as a stored procedure in a SQL DB or any other place you could implement "application logic".  I have generally always opted for modularity and choice, anticipating that I (or a customer) might want this functionality on top of other data sources.  Plus, I've had MANY instances where the data was spread across multiple databases events in one, time series in another, and I like being able to handle this at the application level.

Author: akoscs
Content: That‚Äòs the thing, i do not think you can write this in flux (yet) you cannot loop through the time segments given by the alarm signal to call the last() on the temp time series, since there are no loops (yet) in flux.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Sure you can - use the map() function.

Author: jeffmorgan.555
Content:
Hi Rick, I just joined this discord to discuss exactly what you have been saying. I've perceived several issues with sparkplug, and would love to get some consesus on the matter:

1. All live data updates are sent on one topic (DDATA) whether you want it or not (on mass this could add significant unwanted load to a network, especially when considering varying frequency rates of data). For example: if I have an application and I want 1 data tag from a device which has 100 data tags, using the sparkplug protocol, I have to receive all 100 data tag updates from the device.

2. depending on the rate of change, the use of DBirth could lead to stale data for listeners which were not connected at the time of the DData update, as such, if the rate of change of the data point is low and the DBirth is not updated regularly, stale data will be present in the system for new connection (this is overcome in basic MQTT, when previous data is retained and can be referenced per topic).

3. Data compression (specifically Google Protocol Buffer) can be a barrier to entry for simple application listeners. While its need is evident in large systems, especially Edge Node to Edge Node, for simple devices / applications this added layer of complexity can block the free flow of information in MQTT networks.

Author: mparris
Content:
You hit on a lot of the limitations of Sparkplug. Although, regarding point number 2, the design of Sparkplug is that when a node joins and starts receiving NDATA or DDATA for something it hasn't received a NBIRTH or DBIRTH, it should send an NCMD/DCMD to that node requesting it republish the NBIRTH/DBIRTH.

This solves the problem your have in mind about missing the state of data, but reveals other problems, such as requiring a command path from anywhere in the Enterprise to the Sparkplug node (which may not be desirable, especially if the device is on the plant floor and it should not have any inbound paths. Also, if there are a thousand nodes, then that could be a thousand BIRTH requests coming in, which the device may or may not be able to handle.

Author: mparris
Content:
For a deeper look at Sparkplug, I recommend this article I published last month:

https://www.linkedin.com/posts/matthewparris_november-2022-industrial-ethernet-book-activity-7000937140515733504-hMQp?utm_source=share&utm_medium=member_android

Author: jeffmorgan.555
Content: Ok missed this, thank you for updating me on how point 2 is overcome to some degree

Author: jeffmorgan.555
Content: Thank you for sharing this, lengthy article, I'll review in detail and get back to you

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Most historians do interpolation, its one of the things they do fairly well. I know at least two where you choose how to handle the boundaries, either by interpolation or last value.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: It's not really the interpolation that's the issue though.  It's using the timestamp of an independent event to determine the boundaries of the value(s) to interpolate that is the tricky part.

Author: jeffmorgan.555
Content: Firstly Mathew, thank you for writing/sharing this article, it was very enjoyable to read, and I have now subscribed to the ‚ÄúIndustrial Ethernet Book‚Äù publication as a result. In particular I like your ‚ÄòData Access Model‚Äô for comparing protocols / standards (e.g. MQTT, OPC UA, Sparkplug), I will certainly share your article with my network as I believe you have hit some key points.

Author: jeffmorgan.555
Content:
If possible I would like to get your thoughts on a couple of areas which could use more focus:
1. The negative effect of Industry 4.0, in which data interoperability is being restricted for monetary reasons. In the past aligning to protocols was a means of better market adoption and integration, and now we are faced with high costs for simple data access, which absolutely limits scalability regardless of what protocol is in place.
2. Low-code and No-code becoming a deciding factor for engineers, which is in-line with your statement regarding ‚Äúmaking the integration of data consumer applications painless‚Äù, however I believe this is more prevalent than realized, as engineers seek quick ways to move data from A to B without realizing the negative effects of the decisions made. For example, the issues I/we raised with Sparkplug, which is useful in the right situations, but not everywhere, especially not on scale for all IT / OT interoperability.
3. Good Marketing versus reality, history has taught us that the best technology is not always the most popular, especially not immediately, I draw reference between the rivalry of Edison and Tesla with DC and AC power transmission. Sometimes the popular vote is misleading, which inherently will slow down technology development, which in this case would be achieving truly interoperable manufacturing systems.
4. Automation of Device Gateways which currently is currently poorly implemented / limited, could be a serious gamechanger for heterogeneous manufacturing system communication. While we wait to see if one medium of industrial communication and data modeling can become a reality, the automation of varied system integration and master data alignment is possible. Scaling system integration could be as easy as adding a new row to a database while automation / validation scripts take care of the rest.

Author: jeffmorgan.555
Content:
Personally, my favorite part of MQTT is its data agnostic capabilities. Even if some systems in my network will use sparkplug, it wont effect other networks I have using the same broker which are not. This flexibility has been key for me with the expanding requirements of smart factories. In contrast OPC UA maybe robust and detailed, I have found it to also be at times convoluted. Future factories will not always have same staff capable of maintaining such complex specifications. I believe you have covered this well in your article in relation to the alignment in OPC UA services between different vendors. However, I am not sure what will prevail in the end, as mentioned in your article and the points above, the matter is complex. Right now I personally am not looking for ‚Äúone protocol to rule them all‚Äù, but I am looking for insight in where to use what protocol, and methods to ease integration, scale, and cost.
(Also if conversation is not inline with the "product-recommendations" please let me know and I will move to a more specific thread)

Author: rickbullotta
Content: You don't need one protocol to rule them all, but you do need: Discoverable data and metadata, easy to interpret and parse data formats, event-driven capabilities, and request/response capabilities.  Many IIoT platforms can provide this normalization.  And yes, know what to use when and where is important, and it's important to ignore those who tell you that Sparkplug should be used everywhere, that MQTT should be the hub for all data access, and that OPC UA is all you need.

Author: trentc
Content:
PYTHON SERVER?
Has anyone found a product, or set up a server that can be managed remotely, preferably with a web ui that is designed to host and execute python apps/scripts?
Yes I understand that I can just run linux and put python on it and SSH in....but...I'm looking for something more streamlined, easier to manage and with tools and configuration for viewing, monitoring, triggering or scheduling the apps.
Yes, I understand that ignition has python and provides lots more, but it's expensive and the expense cannot be justified for this use case.

Author: akoscs
Content: So...there are many options. Python uses Flask, FastAPI, http.server and django as a webserver. Flask and FastAPI do have a Prometheus exporter which allows Prometheus (open source) to monitor your webapp on the reqest-reply level. You can add a Prometheus client to your application and add the metric you want to monitor and all of them will end up in your prometheus instance. You can use Grafana to create nice dashboard for yout prometheus data. This is monitoring. I am not sure what you mean by managing the server. You can containerize your applications and use Portainer to mange the containers in a UI. You can try Backstage which should be more complex as it offers more feature on the development side. To manage infrastruce you can try Terraform or Ansible.

Author: brianpribe
Content: Looking for an affordable RFID reader to mount onto enclosures for operators to scan their ID badges. Rs232, Ethernet, or USB. @elbon_g

Author: elbon_g
Content:
What band would you want, or do you have a particular RFID manufacturer or technology in sight already?
There are tons of options nowadays. If it's a simple ID function, I still prefer 13.56 MHz and the good old ISO15693 tags, especially when a bit more distance than close proximity is a plus. It's also a kind of fallback standard for most 13.56 MHz readers, so there's usually a bigger choice in cheaper readers and tags.

Author: elbon_g
Content: If you're happy with proxy, then NTAG 213 is an ISO/IEC14443 Type A system, which seems very popular right now. Most of my readers that do 13.56 MHz accept both tags, so this may seem like a good start for a generic ID badge authorisation.

Author: brianpribe
Content: I‚Äôm looking for more of a plug n play product with IP65ish rating

Author: elbon_g
Content: I'll take a look around, because there are so many even with decent IP ratings, but that's what is basically under the hood. Know your band, and understand the different standards, that's all, really. BTW, if your smartphone has an NFC function, it will be able to read the above card types...

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @elbon_g, you just advanced to level 1!

Author: brianpribe
Content: There are a TON for sure. Closest one I‚Äôm considering is an M12 like RFID sensor with IO-Link, but my problem is that the machine I‚Äôm building is VERY cost constrained.

Author: elbon_g
Content: From Balluff? Those will be expensive, for sure. If your application is cost sensitive, don't push for IP, just find a cheap reader module and cover it up with plastic or encapsulate it in resin, etc.

Author: elbon_g
Content: I worked on several ATEX type applications where encapsulation was the only real option. It works and its cheap. The resin has a different dielectric constant from air, but that won't detune a 13.56 MHz antenna to the point where it won't do near-field reading...

Author: elbon_g
Content: Also, encapsulation will give you much better IP than 65, more like 68.

Author: brianpribe
Content: Ooooo I like that idea

Author: elbon_g

Author: elbon_g
Content: The choice in RFID solutions has become huge and quite confusing during the past decade or so, but the 13.56 MHz band and the ISO15693 and ISO14443 type tags are the easiest ways to solve these ID badge type problems. Since RF happily passes through plastic, encapsulation is always an option for both readers and tags for a decent IP grade.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Yeah, I thought the encapsulation was interesting. I'm an Amateur Radio operator so I'm familiar with velocity factor. The speed of electricity in a bare copper wire antenna is significantly different then in an insulated wire. When working the 80m band (around 3.5MHz) it comes out to feet differences in antenna length.

Author: elbon_g
Content: But remember, this is a seriously near-field situation where the magnetic field characteristics of the antenna are much more important than the electric. That's partly why magnetic loop antennas are the way to go here. These are "electically small" antennas compared to the wavelength at 13.56 MHz. The only thing that you can detune by pouring resin over it is the matching circuit, but I was never able to screw that up so far. Of course, I haven't ever attempted the same with a variable air capacitor in that circuit... üôÇ

Author: elbon_g
Content: These are all NTAG213 types that we eventually tested with encapsulation for an ATEX environment. All passed with flying colours. You'll notice that they are also intended for "on metal" applications all having a ferrite substrate, which could detune the antenna even further. That shows how robust shortwave RFID technology is now. Although these are all tags, reader antennas behave the same.

Author: elbon_g
Content: I can see no nickel cores here. The silver ones are aluminium foil prints on PC with a kind of spot welding(!) linking the two ends of the coil. The other printed types are on various plastics and FR-4. Those four super tiny ones on the left are copper coils on ferrite cores with the NTAG chip at the bottom.

Content: Let me rephrase, is the ferrite substrate nickel. I recall some issues with Iron on PCB's so thought they used nickel substrates.

Author: elbon_g
Content: The ferrous substrate is basically ferrite powder embedded in soft foamy plastic. You can also buy it as self-adhesive sheets or in a tape form. I don't remember any of the datasheets mentioning nickel, but they could be out there. These are very black and magnetic.

Author: he1ium
Content:
So the problem I am tackling is that the business is using a lot of excel/word/pdf based documents to save the business related data. It has come to a point where it is pretty clear what data the business holds, yet we don't know for a fact which document in which directory or if it has any copies that might have updated information in a different directory. 
An early stage of getting rid of this issue would be to provide a search tool that would allow searching for all documentsmentioning the search phrase while the long term solution of designing and implementing database or any other solution that avoids having large  number of gigabytes of spreadsheets is designed and implemented

Author: brianpribe
Content: A neat trick I've been wanting to implement for inputs that log a high amount of data (temp, vibration, etc) is recording the deltas where the derivative is greater than a certain threshold. Meaning, if a temp sensor reads every 50ms, the edge device logs only when the difference between two readings is greater than say 0.1 C.

Author: hobbes1069

Author: mattmigchelbrink
Content:
mattyice:
implement a digital low pass filter with deadband

chatGPT:
import numpy as np
from scipy.signal import butter, lfilter

def butter_lowpass(cutoff, fs, order=5):
    nyquist = 0.5 * fs
    normal_cutoff = cutoff / nyquist
    b, a = butter(order, normal_cutoff, btype='low', analog=False)
    return b, a

def lowpass_with_deadband(input_signal, cutoff, fs, deadband):
    # Calculate filter coefficients
    b, a = butter_lowpass(cutoff, fs)

    # Initialize input and output variables
    output_signal = np.zeros(len(input_signal))
    prev_output = 0.0

    # Apply the filter
    for i in range(len(input_signal)):
        # Apply the filter coefficients
        current_output = lfilter(b, a, input_signal[i])

        # Check if the output falls within the deadband range
        if np.abs(current_output - prev_output) <= deadband:
            current_output = prev_output

        # Update output and previous output values
        output_signal[i] = current_output
        prev_output = current_output

    return output_signal

Author: hobbes1069
Content:
Got part count working using an `AFTER INSERT` trigger to calculate it and populate the field!
```sql
-- Create a function to update part_count_delta on insert
CREATE OR REPLACE FUNCTION public.update_part_count_delta()
 RETURNS trigger
 LANGUAGE plpgsql
AS $function$
DECLARE
  previous_part_count INTEGER;
BEGIN
  SELECT part_count INTO previous_part_count
  FROM plates_makino_mills
  WHERE asset = NEW.asset
  ORDER BY time DESC
  LIMIT 1 offset 1;
  
  NEW.part_count_delta := NEW.part_count - previous_part_count;
  
  UPDATE plates_makino_mills
  SET part_count_delta = NEW.part_count_delta
  where _id = new._id;
 
  RETURN NEW;
END;
$function$
;

CREATE TRIGGER part_count_delta_after_insert_trigger
AFTER INSERT ON plates_makino_mills
FOR EACH ROW
EXECUTE FUNCTION update_part_count_delta();
```

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Couldn't there be a timing/race condition without an explicit lock?  I guess in your case you know that only one app is pushing updates and that you won't get some in parallel?  Specifically the first SELECT statement where you lookup the previous part count.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: The short answer is "maybe?"... The longer answer is that only Highbyte is writing to the table, and even if something else was, it wouldn't be for the same asset.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Got it.  This is also an interesting case where MQTT broker extensions could be super useful.  The idea of an atomic "trigger" that runs at the broker/UNS to do these types of calculations feels quite natural.  Obviously you'd need a broker that supports both retained values and extensions.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: In this case, I think a SQL trigger is appropriate. I'm pulling a macro from the CNC machine which increments on cycle complete. Most consumers want the part/cycle count, not the cumulative part count.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Yup - just thinking out loud about ways to enhance a UNS with these types of incremental calculations.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Honestly, that would have been the direction I would look to go before I learned about database triggers. I'm not a DBA by any stretch of the imagination, but have been learning a lot about it lately. ChatGPT has helped quite a bit, but some of the Postgres code it creates isn't QUITE right, but definitely saved me a lot of time.

Author: ravil1
Content:
In OPC UA it is called "deadband". Can be defined in percentages, or as absolute values.
If the server does not support deadbands, our product can be configured to implement it itself before sending data to the database.

Author: ravil1
Content: How about Grafana? It has MQTT data source plugin, so dashboards with data coming from MQTT is easy to build. It is open source, and for small projects, you can use also hosted in the cloud instance for free.

Author: akoscs
Content: Grafana has an MQTT datasource, but in my experience, it does not retain data if you use the datasource, it just displays the values it gets while the panel the values are displayed on is active. So you can only use it for momentary values, no real history.

Author: ravil1
Content: Yes, with MQTT data source in Grafana, as in general with MQTT, you get only the latest value, no history. In the question, MQTT is a given condition, so I guessed history is not required.

Author: akoscs
Content: Almost no communication protocols support historical values, so the fact that this is MQTT is nothing special, it could be anything else instead of MQTT. In applications I saw, history is relevant in 99% of the cases when the data is coming form a PLC.

Author: ravil1
Content: You can also use our ogamma Visual Logger for OPC instead of Telegraf. It can log to all these destinations. In the current version, you need to run separate instances for each destination though (one for MQTT, and another for InfluxDB/PostgreSQL).

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Doesn't work that well.  Correlation of results to requests is problematic, each client needs their own subscription channel for each method call (leads to topic bloat), requests can also be "intercepted" by anyone who subscribes to them - lots of issues.  Needs to be more low level and abstracted away via the client and publisher SDKs, along with ideally providing a synchronous facade.

Author: douglawrie
Content: Has anyone got some good takes on HiveMQ vs Chariot brokers? Main downside to Chariot as far as I can tell at the moment is no clustering features. But otherwise I prefer the web interface and I like the whole Sparkplug aware business. Hive often talks about enormous scalability but I don‚Äôt think our use case will ever require it

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I happen to like the people at HiveMQ, I like that HiveMQ is both open source and that it has an excellent extensibility and API model.  They have a growing ecosystem also.  Lastly, I‚Äôve found HiveMQ‚Äôs support to be super responsive and excellent.

Author: douglawrie
Content: They were our default choice but they‚Äôve been pretty hesitant to give any idea of pricing so far üòí

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Well, since you don't need clustering, can't you use the Community Version for now?  That price is clearly published at $0.00.

Author: rickbullotta
Content:
Also, if you're looking at a cloud hosted version, the pricing is also posted, and is free up to 100 devices/10GB per month

https://www.hivemq.com/mqtt-cloud-broker/

Author: douglawrie

Author: re_engineered
Content:
Getting my feet wet in the discord. I've see that Packt Pub has a fair number of books published now in the IoT space, but wondering which ones are actually worth a closer look?   https://subscription.packtpub.com/search?released=Available&category=IoT%20%26%20Hardware I've consumed a lot of media here on MQTT and UNS, gone deep enough that I can understand the tradeoffs mentioned in the Parris article "How all protocols fail at data access interoperability", so not a helpless case- but looking more lower-level info on the 'how'. 

I work with a manufacturer that has a large Oracle-based MES system already, but isn't monitoring any secondary ops at the edge; need to start documenting best practices for PLC tagging and edge gateway deployment (beyond just picking MQTT as a protocol) and getting that data to the cloud lake (where there's already some basic data-merging and graphing). I'm assuming my best path forward short-term is an RTA AB MQTT gateway -> HiveMQ -> ODBC connector to roll out a test line, but want to get deeper into this in general so looking for some heavier reading material. Thank you

Author: brianpribe
Content: I've read like one book on packt and they were good. I haven't been able to use it as much as I'd like.

Author: brianpribe
Content: What do you mean by secondary ops?

Author: re_engineered
Content: Downstream assembly or packaging cells after molding. No data is stored currently except within those machines themselves. Upstream mold parameters are tracked, but not the subsequent steps, so there's interest to install a minimum viable gateway to test data collection from one cut station. I generally understand ISA95 topic structure and SpB to an extent, but would like to read more about recommendations for naming the topics/mapped tags (so they parse well higher up), & to understand payload format or QoS conventions better in SpB (what details do I need to think of in broker configuration to persist data long enough for legacy cloud to grab it, and if on a future line we wanted to have an OEM preconfigure a system to publish vision inspect imgs not just tag info, how do I need to tell them to construct the payload). On this first one, it would likely be myself configuring the gateway/broker with basic tags then letting the data guys combine the broker data with the workorder data already in the cloud for a dashboard- so understanding how to get the topics out of the broker and to a database would be my first step. So, I suppose I am looking to start with a deeper dive on SpB payloads and connectors/APIs. Most of the material out there seems pretty focused on AWS/Azure integration, but I wasn't sure which other material would be best suited.

Author: sherylmccrary
Content: Hi Ree. This is getting into larger architecture questions as well, and how to design the UNS to reflect the overall structure of your business or manufacturing process, which is unique to your organization. Articles will only get you so far. I'll see if I can get you some guidelines from one of our SAs.

Author: varghesejm
Content: Hi @Pete Larochelle this question has gotten muddy over the last few years so it's important to cover what you mean by mapping. What are you interested in? Physical network topology for just the switches and other network hardware? Physical network topology including where HOSTS are connected (what IP on what port)? Or are you more interested in Logical mapping such as traffic flows (Host A is talking to Host B using XYZ proto and ABC data rate)? I can provide some feedback based on your answers.

Author: martinc9133
Content: Hi all, I've browsed through a lot of discussions about adapting allen bradley PLCs to a UNS architecture - was wondering if in a greenfield project today this would be a good option or if its better to search for a supplier with better native support? If so, who are the players I should look at?

Author: rickbullotta
Content: My $0.02 : if your team is familiar with programming and maintaining A-B PLCs, I/O, and so on, I don't think there's a very good business case for switching just for native UNS connectivity, since there are so many great options to address that at the layer above the PLCs.  You will almost certainly get other opinions though.

Author: pydesai4.0
Content: I agree with @RickBullotta . UNS can be achieved on the layer above the PLC. Litmus Edge was developed keeping UNS in mind from day one and is PLC or protocol agnostic.

Author: ravil1
Content:
Dear Discord friends,

If you want your data from OPC UA Servers to be published in UNS in minutes - please consider using our product.

Version 3.0.0 of our flagship product - ogamma Visual Logger for OPC has been released!
With it, you can start collecting data from OPC UA Servers and store & forward it to the cloud or in-prem databases in minutes. No need to manually browse OPC UA Server address space, neither drug nor drop nor edit configuration files manually. Just define your variables' browsing and selection logic in Python scripts - and the rest will be done in a minute. For example, MQTT topics can be composed automatically particularly using variables' browse paths.
If you would like to have historical data too - with it you can also log your data to InfluxDB, or Kafka, or SQL databases.
The product can be supplied either as software only, or we can ship it to you pre-installed on an industrial PC. In the latter case, there is an option to maintain the OS and application completely remotely at the fleet level.

In this video, end-to-end data flow from the OPC UA Server to the HiveMQ broker running in the cloud is demonstrated: https://youtu.be/MLfYwUlTGLA

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Plus the hours spent trying to configure security and certs?

Author: rickbullotta
Content: If you could develop tools to make the security setup process super easy, that might be very valuable.

Author: ravil1
Content:
You will need to deal with certificates no matter what product you use to move data from OPC UA to MQTT or other targets securely. If you decide to use NodeRed or HighByte, you will have the same problem. Or rather one more configuration step.
This proposal is for use cases when data is available over OPC UA according to the customer's design or real situation, and now they want to move it without spending too much time and resources.
This is a good note that if we want to go further and automatically discover all servers and automatically connect to them, to make the connection part to work you will need to solve problem of certificates trust. The simplest way for that to configure trust for each connection manually, which can take a few more minutes, not hours, if you know what you are doing.  Or to use certificates signed by CA and set up trust to these well-known CA certificates. Open source GDS can be used for that, or generic  certificate management solution.
Here I think it is important to have the right, competent partners.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Agreed, though I think we can also develop better tools to make this process "one click".  The OPC UA foundation should make this a priority and should open source the tools.

Author: ravil1
Content:
It is easier on MQTT side because often the broker is on the cloud and have a certificate issued by a well-known root CA certificate which is pre-installed on most operating systems. They are pre-configured in our product too, so no need to download for example HiveMQ certificate and establish trust manually. 
But if you decide to use authentication of MQTT clients by certificate, then will have the same problems as with OPC UA in general.
You could also configure OPC UA server to trust all clients similar to what MQTT brokers do, and use only session level authentication.

Author: zeratall
Content: Lol I was thinking this the other day when I had to go update a bunch of certs. Maybe time to start a new repo lol

Author: akoscs
Content: Letsencrypt was a gamchanger for IT. Free certs which are automatically provisioned.  For internet facing applications being a Trusted CA was key, but for intranet facing equipment that is not a must. What industrial equipment has the feature to update/add a cert in a non manual way?

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: Ignition supports the use of Let's Encrypt, but it requires port 80 or access to a DNS server. I can't imagine many clients wanting to expose this. That said, manual certs do not require much effort and validity can be extended beyond the standard 1 year. But it would be great to have for sure.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Have you setup certs for OPC UA architectures?  I personally have not, but all the anecdotal information I've heard is that is time consuming and complex.  Would welcome insights from those who have been through it!

Author: akoscs
Content: Only manually, did not look into automated provisioning for OPC UA. It was as cumbersome as any cert gets, try windows, you get fed up cause something is missing for the Openssl instalation (now its better with win11)  then get a WSL but it has  suddenly strange error. You get a dockerized ubuntu running and think about why did you not do this in the firs place, you look up why shared volume is not working, you fix the small typo in the command then you finally generate the certs. I mean...it wasn't worse then any other cert update. TIA portal now even generates OPC UA server certs for you.

Author: ravil1
Content:

Author: vatsalshah
Content:
Hey that's us - Happy to answer the question with some facts üôÇ 

One of the finest not-so-known UNS is Manufacturing Data Engine (Google's product). They never marketed as UNS.

1. It includes GCP Pubsub -> Cloudscale ingress layer. Pay as you go and scales nicely with unbeatable SLA.  You can scale millions of msgs/second and it won't break.
2. GCP flow -> translating multiple data format (including Litmus Edge JSON) to 1 standardized format and it is configurable. It also creates Hierarchy + UNS type layout.
3. GCP Bigquery + Bigtable -> instant push into DB for various analytics 
4. Looker -> Build your own apps / BI 

Yes if you plan to stay in GCP ecosystem, this is a slam dunk.

For Local UNS + Bridging 
1. Manufacturing Connect Edge (Litmus Edge) on OT layer -> Manufacturing Connect Edge (Litmus Edge) on IT layer via using NATS Proxy protocol. 
2. Use the built-in MQTT brokers in MC and scale it up 

If you are considering UNS at Scale, please do get in touch with GCP/Litmus team.

Author: drainoo
Content: what do you think are the 10 yr implications that chatgpt etc.. are trained on publicly available data (in this case hobbyist hardware like pi / arduino) and are therefor much more adept at generating working programs for those platforms vs. more traditional / esoteric (read - vendor specific)  platforms?

Author: rickbullotta
Content: The 10 year trend will reinforce current practices and regress real innovation.  LLMs are inherently backwards facing and that will prove to be problematic

Author: hiptopjones
Content: Yeah, definitely will be important to avoid future AIs being trained on AI-generated garbage.  I think the time delay gap will be closed pretty quickly.  The internet itself is inherently backwards facing, and hasn't been so bad.  And I tend to think of something like ChatGPT as really just a more immersive connection to the internet.

Content: i see where you guys are coming from but my friend - a blue collar welder guy with no computer savvy used chatgpt to write the code for a custom medical device he built for himself that is solving his rare jaw-condition (it's an arduino with an input pin wired to a switch he places inside his mouth at night and the output goes to a relay that shocks him with a 9v battery in the gumline if he clenches his jaw at night and writes out a logfile of all his jaw clenches so he can monitor his progress.  He could never have hoped to accomplish that without tens or more hours of research even just a few years ago.

Content: GG @av8or1ab, you just advanced to level 1!

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Databricks as a historian seems to me an absolutely absurd idea.

Author: av8or1ab
Content: The argument from that team is that it can ingest the data via some HighByte magic and they can build dashboards using their platform, which they are already doing. This is an artifact of having an analytics group that already provides metrics to the business.

Author: av8or1ab
Content: Like I said it doesn‚Äôt sit well but I‚Äôd like to have a well formed argument other than, ‚ÄúThat seems overly complex and untested‚Äù

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Expensive, inherent latency unless you want to spend a lot and add other streaming componentry, will be a pain to configure and maintain, availability concerns if you‚Äôre using this to support realtime operations, and yet another user interface for the operations folks.  I‚Äôd use a local time series DB or historian for real time operations support and sync that in batches to Databricks or some other cloud repository for dashboards and analytics (HighByte can handle that).  It‚Äôs going to cost a ‚Äúshit ton‚Äù (technical term) to go the route they want to go I think.

Author: patanj2
Content: Do you have data engineers on your team?  The reason I ask is that DataBricks,  while I think it is a great platform,  is targeted towards users being data engineers and data scientists,  not process engineers or operations personnel.  So if you want to enable your users,  then the right choice depends on who your users are and what are their skill sets.  Sure DataBricks is also a good choice if your products are BI dashboards/reporting.  But there is a lot more functionality in any historian product than just storage.   Retrieval speed is very important when looking at interactive time series charts.  Historians excels at retrieving a small number of tags for a wide time period quickly.  A data lake or Cloud Data Platform  excels at different types of analysis and queries.

Author: av8or1ab
Content: It‚Äôs a sister team and yes they have data engineers. I agree that analytics is a different use case than operations. It‚Äôs a bit of a catch 22 right now where we don‚Äôt have it so we can‚Äôt show them. Just like Walker talks about what you want is a function of what you know, they don‚Äôt know yet because we can‚Äôt show them.

Author: patanj2
Content: Use case where a cloud data platform would likely do poorly:  ad hoc troubleshooting:   A line just when down or is performing poorly and users are trying to troubleshoot in close to real time.  Users look at multiple parameter,  constantly zoom in zoom out and scroll back and forth in time.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: And if you're using your cloud data to support real-time operations, just having a trend chart up all the time and constantly querying the backend could rack up some big time cloud charges.

Cases where CDP is better fit than historian

Broad and large scale queries where you are trying to query and/or summarize  a large number of assets or tags‚Äî there are workaround,  but a with a historian it may struggle with thes first two. Ad hoc data science work.

Author: red_sun9
Content:
Hi 

i need a HMI recommendation
We are looking to add an gui to operator station that will controls few of factory equipment. We have a mix of GE and AB PLCs. Currently we have a Proficy Cimplicity that seems overkill for the application that we have, and with not so good product support we are looking to move away from it

Two of the major requirement for our new HMI is to
- have its own inbuilt operating system such that if the hmi breaks, we replace it by just using another unit from our spares and its ready to go
( we have had a lot of issues in past where when our current system broke down we would have to get IT involved, takes forever to get the right windows settings that are compliant with all policies and what not, losing valuable production time)
- has a decent historian data storage and view as regulations need us to store upto 30days of data on the operator station itself. taht historical data needs to be available even if their is network outage (overall network is segregated and current HMI and about 7-8 foundry equipment sit in one area, on one VLAN such that when netwrok is up and running they talk to main historian server, but are also capable of running if for any reason the network goes down)

We looked at Panelview but decided against it as it needs kepware to talk to GE PLCs
looked at Ignition/Aveva hmis, but not going for that as we still have get IT involved in getting a pc configured for these. I thought about Ignition Edge but there is a limit on how many devices you can connect, plus for GE PLCs i need kepware.. 

any suggestions?

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Regarding "it's own inbuilt operating system" you can also just clone the storage drive.  SSDs are cheap. You'll still need to backup/install your application though, which you could do as part of this periodic cloning.  Call QMation - they can get you fixed up with some combo of HW + SW so you don't need to get IT involved.

Author: red_sun9
Content:
we use Acronis right now for cloning, issue usually comes up with procuring hardware, as our current policies restrict us getting new "PC"
plus the new cloned computer still needs license activation et all, which we are hoping to put behind us using a standalone HMI

Author: zeratall
Content:
So I know this product has been talked about already by walker and members here, but man, Intelligence Hub (https://www.highbyte.com/intelligence-hub.html) really speeds up development! I think a lot of "low code" tools try to make things more accessible to speed up deployment, but a lot fall flat and while some make things a little easier, they can be slower then just coding something up. Now that i've used IH for about a year at NG I can tell you it delivers on the "low-code" vision!  

I'm in the process of making a representative IT/OT architecture at home for a video series, where I want to go into technical details of I4.0, aka How to Model I4.0 using MBSE, What a UNS with different types of names spaces and integrations looks like (MES, OT, etc), How permissions can be applied to a UNS, and a whole lot of other demos I want to do. For this architecture, I want to demonstrate the power of having a DataHub in the stack, because I'm having to do this out of my own pocket, __**I've been building my own Hub in C#/.NET, and it pains me, a code base I've made to subscribe, define events, transform, pulish, and pipelines, has taken me a few days, where if I was using IH would have taken me a few minutes! **__

Author: akoscs
Content: You know or use python. Also just a few minutes :)))) (I am a huge .net fan but ‚Ä¶ in many cases python is waay more efficient for implementation)

Author: zeratall
Content: Hahahah that is fair, I have a lot more experience with .NET which is why I've gone with it, I've put off python for so long because of the syntax, but the amount of libaries and adoption of Python has made me start investing more time into it lol.

Author: hobbes1069

Author: zeratall
Content: Hahaha, moral of the story, I'm a little biased in my programming choices still =P, but IH is still a fantastic tool, and can really speed things up when your talking about implementing/deploying I4.0 architecture.

Author: vaughnturner
Content:
Here is the response from our Solutions Architect, Michael Walker.

Michael Walker
Specifically answering the Ignition "From Scratch" portion of the post. Look at the Systems Integration community who work with Ignition, that build MES "software kits",  "accelerators" or "frameworks" in general outside of Sepasoft module(s).  
 
Intellic has an MES that we generally start with to quickly deploy projects. 
 
Some other integrators are using Kanoa MES, or Spark as linked below. 
 
https://kanoa.ai/kanoa-mes-overview
 
https://www.flexwareinnovation.com/spark-mes/ 
 
Each of these systems are installed openly on Ignition AFAIK, from there you get MES functionality quickly, but then are in an open platform (Ignition) to continue expanding on use cases, feature development, customization, etc...   This is my mind is the best of both worlds (CUSTOM vs COTS)
 
Hopefully this helps clarify a bit.

Author: brianpribe
Content: If that statement was true, Litmus wouldn't be doing so hot right about now. I've been looking at how your marketplace would suffice as THE OT management system. The problem today is that we have tons of different applications we could use that are docker-based, but you need a kubernetes cluster to maintain HA and HR. Your product, along with everything else that Edge delivers, is unbeatable.

Author: vatsalshah
Content:
True - i meant more like General Purpose marketplaces. Lets say someone builds apps on your "platform" and you take care of bringing that app to mass market is much more difficult. And majority of complexities are non-tech. 

Litmus Edge "App" Marketplace had no commercialization angle. So our own customers' IT teams / Data Scienece teams could distribute apps to their own Sites / Plants. Worked out very well and no pressure for us to be a catalyst in a true sense. 
Your statement on "OT Management System" will get true when trifecta of Infrastructure, Data & App orchestration will be done by a single vendor. May be K8S will help.

Author: brianpribe
Content: I'm assuming Edge and Edge Manager has K8S running in the background?

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Ummm...that's kind of the point.

Author: vatsalshah
Content:
Nope - no K8S as a core but very compliant with existing K8S infra.

Litmus Edge 
- Started as Baremetal / ISO - built with Yocto (mostly to be semi-deterministic performance / security first - all components run as SystemD üôÇ )
- OVA
- Docker images 
- K8S help / operators 

Litmus Edge Manager 
- Started as OVA VM - built with Packer
- Cloud VMs
- K8S helm / operators

Author: brianpribe

Author: vatsalshah
Content:
Yepp this image is for VM / ISO version of Litmus Edge. 
Essentially all components inside Litmus Edge (Devicehub aka drivers, datahub aka broker/db, intragretions, analytics, Digital twins) are working as a SystemD. We wanted to go as close as possible to HW for performance. 
Now if customers bring their own apps, they can do it in docker environment. Where above diagram is showing.

Author: vatsalshah
Content:
These are the services inside Litmus Edge  - all of them running on Linux directly. 
Docker has so many failure points - we just wanted to avoid in favor of robustness

Author: rickbullotta

Author: rickbullotta

Author: vatsalshah
Content: Cloud Connect üòâ  - we stopped using that word in favor of Integrations. API names never changed as we were forced to do backwards compatibility.

Author: vatsalshah
Content:
True - there are many way to orchestrate HA / Failover and most of them depends on where Litmus Edge is running. 
Litmus Edge Manager is more or less "Life cycle management" or orchestration product. Customers have 100s of sites - and 100s of lines and 100s of Litmus Edge across the world. - how do Provision, Upgrade, deploy apps, templates and more - that central management is Litmus Edge Manager. It does help in creating HA but beauty is in Docker rather than us.

Author: brianpribe
Content: Makes a lot of sense. I use Odoo for a lot of my ERP functions, but I have zero need to scale it with K8S. SystemD with consistent backups to AWS volumes and the ability to increase the VM resources is all I need at this point. Major updates to Odoo are my only weakness since they modify the database so much that having K8S wouldn't help.

Author: vatsalshah
Content:
100% - Not every workload needs to be stateless, serverless, autoscaled, and fancy data meshes on them. 
Industrial customers want consistent performance and robustness. VMs are generally better when apps are not changing that often. One of our biggest time and money suck was building and stabilizing Litmus Edge on Yocto images. Like a whole year in 2018 (for startups, it's an eternity) ! But once Yocto images were built, it got so easy for us to keep launching new features and provide better security.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Plex‚Äôs maintenance module has not been enhanced in several years.  It‚Äôs been true to itself pre-acquisition because it‚Äôs not really a core module that in phase 1 implementations.  It tends to be adopted if customers desire to consolidate their solutions or they don‚Äôt really have a strong incumbent CMMS.  Most of it was developed for specific SMB customers 10+ years ago.  Some of procurement integration for supplies/spares is kind of neat.  It‚Äôs also nice how the work requests can be reviewed and opened from the shop floor MES screen.  It provides a way to integrate frequent PM (e.g., daily, shift) into production.  I wouldn‚Äôt recommend Plex for CMMS unless Plex is already in the architecture and the maintenance program is not very sophisticated.

Plex overall has remained relatively ‚Äúindependent‚Äù post-acquisition because the product and engineering leadership largely took over Rockwell‚Äôs software business units.  Before this, Rockwell didn‚Äôt really do SaaS or services.

The bigger issue is that, for quite a while, Plex have not really kept pace as the platform and architecture has aged.  They‚Äôre going on 10 years now of a new UX project with a significant share of their legacy install base still on classic.  Major enhancements only really happen for securing large customers or getting their implementations across the finish line.  They have had a poor track record in recent years keeping up with delivery of a compliance functionality (e.g., USMCA customs, AIAG+VDA FMEA v5, Foundation FMEA).

Plex is just at a mature investment stage.  It‚Äôs two things at this point.  First, it‚Äôs recurring revenue among a customer base in which it‚Äôs too costly to switch.  Second, there is still untapped market of manufacturers with legacy ERP/MES or nothing at all.  To these organizations, anything is an improvement over what they have.  Accelerated road map delivery and aggressive refactors are not in the works.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Completely agree.  Maintenance is very much a ‚Äúpeople‚Äù function.  If the interfaces aren‚Äôt catered to the task at hand and they‚Äôre inefficient, it‚Äôs a disaster.  CMMS/EAMs become easily become red tape rather than a productive tool if they‚Äôre not deployed properly

Tulip could be really useful for maintenance activity.  It would be an amazing interface for maintenance technicians.  The problem is that it doesn‚Äôt have the ‚ÄúMDM‚Äù backbone necessary for a major maintenance program.  I don‚Äôt know how it could handle scheduling, supplies / procurement integration, and asset BOMs.  For example, a plant can have like hundreds or thousands of pumps with lots of variations.  A good PM solution would allow to define base level activity with additional activity for the variability.  It then must be associated with assets and then scheduled (e.g., by frequency, by time, by condition).  It would be cumbersome to build all of this out from a front interface.  It needs a back end data model with a set of logic to orchestrate everything.  Imagine if PM content relevant to all pumps needs to be revised or added.  That could entail updating hundreds of pump records and thousands of scheduled maintenance orders.

On the other side of the coin, while they have better management features, the user interface of many CMMS is not great.

Author: vikanchira
Content: Is Kepware and PTC any good? I would assume that Kepware can do similar thing to Ignition? What is the pros/cons? Can't subscribe to SparkplugB? Can't subscribe to MQTT? ü§î

Author: d_leblanc
Content: Kepware/PTC has a lot more drivers the ignition does. out the 6000+ machines we are connected to, 60% of them a Fanuc controls which Ignition does not have a driver for, then 25% Allen Bradley, 10% Siemens and the rest are GE, Mitsubishi, Omron, Modbus & Toyopuc, MTConnect. This is a small percentage of what Kepware supports. No Sparkplug B  but you can sub to MQTT, publish with IoT Gateway plugin. There is no HMI component to Kepware so its more of a single source for all your machine connections. there is data logger and historian plugin as well. The advanced tag plugin allow you to create send data from machine to machine over different protocols, do logic and math functions to create a tag based on several other tags. I manage about 65 kepware servers and we use it mainly because it is a single product that can connect to almost any machine

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
It also has more driver features than most of the SCADAs.  For example, its Siemens drivers support browsing, automatic tag creation on some S7 models.  Ignition's do not.  Additionally, some drivers can be used in an unsolicited messaging scenario where the PLC will publish over the native protocol instead of polling from Kepware.

The Manufacturing Suite is a great offering.  It can connect to a lot of stuff.

If you're interested in report-by-exception, you're better off using OPC UA Server interface with subscriptions.  The IoT Gateway (with MQTT and REST Client) is kind of clunky as there isn't much control over the payload.  It doesn't support Sparkplug.  Sparkplug doesn't work well with big aggregated namespaces like Kepware anyways.  It's better for smaller device gateways deployed in the field where the application benefits from the state management and compression features.

Author: vikanchira
Content:
I don't 100% get the last part. How big is does the aggregated Namespace has to be? How many aggregated tags?
OPC UA Server interface with subscription? ü§î

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I'll use a more practical example.  In the energy sector, there may be lots of distributed remote assets.  Each asset may have its own capability to directly provide data or it may do so indirectly through its own dedicated gateway.  Another way to think of this is like smart, connected products.  It's lots of distributed nodes.  In manufacturing plants, often, the data sources are aggregated into one or few interfaces such as an OPC Server, Historian, SCADA, gateway, etc.  What the consuming client may connect to might actually have hundreds or thousands of devices behind it.

Some data acqusition technology is well-suited to working with small amounts of data from many data sources, but it does poorly at dealing with very large amounts of data from fewer sources.  This is what the cloud service providers really struggled with when they first got into IIoT.  They thought it was like IoT scenarios where it would be like connected products or fleet management.  They didn't realize that they wouldn't be connecting to or putting their edge runtime on every machine, but instead some gateway that aggregates the namespace.

In the most simple way, working with the data of one node is very different than working with all the nodes in a factory.

OPC UA Servers often have two primary messaging modes: polling or subscriptions.  Polling is when the client retrieves data from the server on an interval.  With subscriptions, the client will subscribe to the tags in the server and the server will publish the values when they update.

Author: hobbes1069
Content:
TLDR version:
Both are good. Tatsoft is .NET based so you're mostly tied to Windows (technically there is MONO for Linux but I haven't tested it) but being MS Stack native it's very fast and doesn't have the same performance limitations as Igintion does since it is Java based. The tradeoff is that Ignition being Java based can run on about anything.

Author: mparris
Content:
Ahhh.  IIoT platform.

I concur with starting with Ignition. The ecosystem surrounding that product to empower new users is unmatched in the industrial world.

As you go on your Digital Transformation journey, you'll Begin to find the limitations of Ignition and start to architect beyond that, either offloading functions from Ignition to more specialized products or building around it with more scalable solutions.

But Ignition has a bit of everything to get you going and learn through experience too know where to go next.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: I‚Äôd say ignition is more ‚Äúmature‚Äù, and has a better developer experience. Ignition is ‚Äúdifferent‚Äù than other SCADA software. Frameworx feels more like other SCADA (when you develop it). Ignitions tag engine is very intuitive, but framework feels more like you‚Äôre working with a database in the backend. At some point this becomes a preference thing, but getting into Ignition is very easy, while getting started with frameworx is a bit more work. Value for money, frameworx is probably the best deal you can get. Heck, they‚Äôve even got a colab with Canary, so you can use Canary unlimited as the native historian database backend (just the high speed/no sql database) in a very good deal. These are my opinions,  having spent perhaps 50 hours with Frameworx and easily more than 1000 with Ignition..

Author: jramirez3
Content: Not sure this is the right thread to ask this but why would someone use Canary Labs historian over Ignition's tag historian if you're using Ignition as your Scada system? I think I have hard time understanding the historian in general. I know in Ignition it stores to Sql and you can also store data in a wide format using transaction groups.

Author: ted.garrison
Content: 1) Ease of access by products other than Ignition.  The Ignition historian does partitioning and such that makes it hard to access the data.   2) Ignitions Historian can't really keep up (at least, it seems to be the case in my experience)

Author: ted.garrison
Content: Also, Canary has some really slick self-service features for folks (such as Maintenance) that want to be able to look at the historical data.

Author: jramirez3
Content: Keep up with what? The Ignition historian does the partitioning to make queries to it quicker using their components for the screens you build in Ignition. We use Ignition so we view the data via Ignition screens.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
To keep up with reads and, in some cases, the writes.  

Relational databases are oriented around certain transactional qualities.  These qualities are desirable and relevant for working with, say, ERP or MES records.  These qualities are not as relevant for handling time series data from OT telemetry.  The Ignition tag historian relies on a conventional relational database.  All the timestamps, tags, values, and datatypes are stored in single, massive table.  This table is partitioned and compressed.

While partitioning and compression can help with performance in some cases, it can have scalability issues and can be less performant in other cases.  It can be inefficient for a database to filter rows across many partitions and run aggregate calculations.  From end user perspective, there may be long query executions or timeouts.  Outside of the SCADA or OT world, it's not uncommon to replicate relational data into an alternative data structure or database technology to better handling analytical workloads.  What is optimal for applications may not necessarily be optimal for analysis.  What is optimal for applications may not necessarily be optimal for telemetry.

If you are all about Ignition and you're not observing issues, continue using Ignition.  These nuances about databases and historians may be less relevant to your projects and applications of the tag historian module.  Using @Ted Garrison's experience with the module as an example, it's more relevant.  Your mileage will vary.

Related post:
https://discord.com/channels/738470295056416930/945394093176029184/1192777315814486096

Author: jramirez3
Content:
@js
Gotcha. I see. At my current company we are not that large yet to run into any long timeouts. 

My question was probably not worded well. Everything is fine using the Ignition tag historian at the moment, I'm trying to figure out what's the actual need of a historian.

Right now if there is a need to look at historical data, usually from an incident, we look at the wide tables (snapshots of all data from a piece of equipment) rather than data stored in the historian. 

Also, since I'm decent at Sql, I'm able to run queries against the data in the wide tables and get great results. 

I think I may need actual examples of how the historian can be more useful than interval snapshot logging.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Your question made perfect sense.  It's a great question.  Historical industrial data "looks" different to different people.

Sometimes it's many individual data streams published, independently of each other, on change or some unique interval.  This is the primary way batch and process industries think about data.  Think of big assets with tons of instrumentation that is always logged.  The users might be more concerned with monitoring and studying long trends in data.  For example, the precise change in the level of a tank over time might be more important than whether tank is at/near a full or empty state.  This where one might use a traditional historian or time series database.  This is where one might have one giant or many "narrow" tables.

Other times, it's an event consisting of a collection of many data points at a very specific time.  This is a more common way discrete manufacturers think about data.  As widgets come off the line or alarms happen, they may want to consume data more like a report or a snapshot of the operation/process.  For example, they may want to log the traceability of a complex assembly and how its bill of materials were consumed.  They may be more concerned with quickly resolving an alarm state, a stoppage, or a nonconforming process.  The position of a robot when it mishandles something and what it's handling (e.g., serial no, lot) may be more useful than the robot's positions before or after the mishandling event.  This is where one might log in "wide" tables in a database.

These scenarios can, of course, be blended across industries.  The discrete people might want to closely monitor the conditions of a critical asset over time.  The process people might need to log some reason code when a process is unexpectedly interupted.  But, what is being produced and how its produced, will largely drive how people think about industrial data.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Interesting side note: a lot of folks who use certain SQL databases to store history size them based on ingest and maybe query - but forget that at some point you may also need to delete/purge/archive data to cold storage.  That load is comparable and sometimes actually even a heavier lift than ingest (due to caching and such).
