Author: jon.forbord
Content:
Here‚Äôs some performance metrics to consider:
Ignition historian:
With MySQL or other standard SQL database ~ 10 000 tag changes per second max write speed. Reads probably slightly more. High performance SQL up to 30 000 tag changes per second.
Canary tag historian:
2-3 000 000 tag changes per second write speed, similar read. So if you‚Äôre below 10k tag changes per second, Ignition is decent. If you‚Äôre approaching tens of thousands, you should probably look at a high performance historian such as Canary.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Canary also have a lot better tools to visualize the data, and can create reports, perform in flight calculations, model the data, comes with an API, OPC connectors etc.. a lot more than just a database.. if the pricing is worth it, compared to other high performance historians it‚Äôs actually one of the cheaper options.

Author: donpancoe
Content: I'm just full of questions this week. Does anybody use test-driven development (unit tests at dev time) when developing Python scripts specifically for Ignition? Simulating complete real-world inputs in a dev environment can be a challenge, but testing in production can be a real no-no. Not to mention that the function you want to test might not get called in a production environment for hours or even days.

Author: ravil1
Content:
With ogamma Visual Logger for OPC we had collection rate close to 500,000 values / second, but the rate of writing to TimescaleDB was only 72,000 values per second. If we turn off indexing in the database table, then would have higher rate. With more optimization like sharding I think could go maybe up to few hundred thousands. 
With InfluxDB forwarding from local instance to the InfluxDB in the cloud the rate was higher, up to 200,000 values per second. 
I am curious, how Canary can have higher rates? Is that single instance running in one super powerfull machine, or they spread the load to multiple machines? In our tests everything is single instance, desktop/small server hardware, nothing like cluster or super powerfull servers.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: The millions per second is with multiple collectors, but to one historian database. Canary does append writes very efficiently, to flat files. I don‚Äôt know more than that really, as the how is part of their secret sauce..

Author: jon.forbord
Content: The server hardware is the pretty normal. Like 16 cores 32 gigs ram..

Author: jon.forbord
Content: I‚Äôm speculating, but it‚Äôs pretty well described how something such as Kafka can do extremely fast writes to the log, bypassing certain elements of the normal write operation. Perhaps something similar is part of the secret sauce.. I don‚Äôt know.

So I have to do kill&fills on a lot of my data.  Which is annoying when I'm generating result sets thru ETL of 2.3 billion rows and it takes an hour plus to run.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Yeah, it's sad to hear about Tableau's "slowdown".  I still really like their visualizations and ux.  But, in order to get the most of tableau it needs to be sitting on a data warehouse or have something like Alteryx for ETL.  Some of the transformations, especially when working with industrial data, can be too much to do in a BI solution.

If you're going through billions of rows, it might be worthwhile exploring an OLAP schema (e.g., stars, cubes).  Another option is to explore a column-oriented database (e.g., AWS Redshift, SQL Server w/ Columnstore).  This can help improve performance on those big aggregate calculations.

If you're comfortable with SQL, Snowflake is a joy.  It's very flexible.  It takes a lot of headaches out managing databases and compute.  I've heard there exist some partner solutions for no code / low code transformations.  In addition to bringing your preferred BI solutions, there are also a lot of interesting solutions for building visualizations and data apps such as Streamlit.

If you're an MS shop and there is already a team in place that is supporting [and funding] Azure, this might make sense to use.  The only concern I would have is some of the changes they've made to their services and strategy in recent years.  Azure Blob Storage, Azure Data Lake Storage Gen1, Azure Data Lake Storage Gen2, Azure Databricks, Azure Synapse, Azure Data Factory, Azure Data Fabric, Azure OneLake, etc.  It would be nice to see more stability and continuity.  They just seem to be all over the place.

Regardless of the cloud solution, make sure workloads are optimized for the native services.  "Lifting and shifting" legacy workloads can get expensive.

Author: r.pop
Content: Most customers use PowerBI or some version of a custom Web App. I would say 90% of manufacturers I talk to are using PowerBI. With the co-pilot stuff coming down the pipe it‚Äôs probably the best option.

Author: autopsias
Content: Have a look at Domo. I did a similar search a while ago and that‚Äôs where I landed. I would recommend it if you want to do more than just Data visualisation. Meaning, ETL, storage (lakehouse), data governance and visualisation. I haven‚Äôt seen much better than them yet‚Ä¶ and I went through the rabbit hole of AWS, Azure, Snowflake, PowerBI, Tableau, the works. If you want to deal with all of the above functionality you will need to have deep pockets to jigsaw a bunch of different tools and platforms or you go with a simpler way and do Domo. Hope it helps.

Trying to figure out why your flow fails at precisely 30 minutes is quite a challenge, and their documentation is fairly horrible for that stuff.  It's like they REALLY want you to go with the cloud hosted version..

But I've heard that MS has really leaned into PowerBI so I'm hoping it's improved.

Which are basically the same information but with less granularity and adding in business data like HR, ERP, etc..

Author: .discrete
Content:
I'm having a difficult time finding MQTT edge gateway options with redundancy/HA functionality. The two I've found are Ignition Edge and FlowFuse. Does anyone have any other recommendations?

It seems to me like this is an obvious requirement, so I'm a little confused as to why I'm having such difficulty finding tools with this capability. It makes me feel like I'm going down the wrong path or thinking about the architecture incorrectly.

Author: avret
Content: What sort of redundancy are you looking for here--software or hardware failure resilience?

Author: .discrete
Content: Software

Author: mparris
Content: What is an "MQTT edge gateway"?

Author: .discrete
Content: In a specific case, it's the thing that goes between a ControlLogix and an MQTT broker to translate EtherNet/IP into MQTT.

Author: mparris
Content: What failure modes are you to trying to mitigate with redundancy/HA capability?

Author: .discrete
Content: Any kind of failure of the edge gateway itself. Let's say data collection is a regulatory requirement in order for a machine to run. Having to stop the machine due to a problem on the PC/vm/container/whatever running the edge gateway is not acceptable.

Author: hobbes1069
Content:
It's a bit of a pain to setup (doesn't scan for tags) but over I like the RTA 460ETCQT-N2E. As far as HA I would buy two and have them publish to separate topics.
https://www.rtautomation.com/product/460etcqt/

Author: .discrete
Content: Thank you very much for the info; however, I'd really prefer built-in HA capability rather than the roll-your-own approach with publishing to separate topics...

I woudl approach the issues as, what applications do I want to use, and then can I configure them redundantly ?

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
I am paranoid about Redundance, 
I learned my Automation with one system Integrators and It used to be two desktop PC's with Intouch, Both set up to use the IO Server on the other machine as a redundancy.

as we moved to Thin Client Architectures we became more sophisticated, but as I moved to the Client side, and then to consult, I was amazed at the number of integrators, who never considered that redundancy might be important. 
Especially when it is an embedded feature of the software they were developing on.

And when they tried to fall back on HA servers, there was always data loss.

It's a Pet Hate of mine.

Author: .discrete
Content:
I assumed the largest audience of this discord is OT people rather than IT people. Is that an incorrect assumption?

I thought I could just ask "Anyone know an mqtt edge gateway with similar redundancy capability to FTLinx?" and everyone would know what I was talking about...

Author: douglawrie
Content: Ignition edge has the functionality you‚Äôre talking about. Is it too expensive?

Author: .discrete
Content: No. I just wanted to know the options available.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
I'm not sure. I define OT as the domain where software impacts on the physical world.
It's more than just programming and ETL, and data processing and Screens.

Software is converted to electrical signals that take action on the real world. 
And the real world is messy and things like noise on signal and physical imperfections come into play i.e. was the interruption in the photocell a product, or a forklift passing by?
OT includes , to me, Safety systems, wiring issues, hardware config

I fear when people talk about OT, It is closer to a Production IT team and further from an Instrument Technician that my own definition is.

Author: mparris
Content:
I've always defined as OT as any technology that is used to manipulate the physical world.

I do wonder where this line between IT and OT should be drawn.  Any suggestions on modifying my definition above to clarify?

Considering the Purdue Model, where would you draw the line between OT and IT?

Relays control power
Remote IO blocks control the Relays
PLCs control the IO Blocks
SCADA/HMI control the PLCs
MES controls the SCADA
ERP controls the MES

It's all on a spectrum, and the further away from direct manipulation of the physical world, the harder it is to call OT.

Getting a bit philosophical, however: ERP (functions) is a first cause for OT, since without sales/inventory/distribution there is no foundation/justification to be controlling the physical world to begin with.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
I really like the idea of a spectrum and  "***the further away from direct manipulation of the physical world, the harder it is to call OT.***" is very good.
I would consider ERP decoupled from OT because it does not directly impact the world. Traditionally that decoupling was paper.
A SCADA on the other hand , press a button and stuff happens ,

MES was the battleground, because I think philosophically the function is execution. But because the skills tended to be from the IT realm( Databases, API and all that stuff which was beyond  many a controls engineer even 10/15 years ago. 

and I think when IT/OT convergence started, it progressed as IT Eating OT and trying to make it conform to IT approaches and ITSM. There are lots of good ideas we can take from ITSM but I prefer to create an OTSM approach.

And I think now the battle for MES is swinging and OT departments have learned the skills, and are taking over.
Maybe ERP will follow, because as the ERP is integrated more into the plant floor, a change in the ERP could cause recipe changes, or automatic starts for Jobs etc.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: In a retail environment, a POS terminal, checkout scanner, and so on are considered OT.  In a fast food restaurant environment, equipment used for refrigeration and food prep are also considered OT.  So it can be just digital, or fully physical.

Author: mparris
Content:
Interesting.  If there is no control of the physical world as in the case of POS terminal...only monitoring the physical world...should that still be counted as OT? Hmm...maybe

(and by the way, I'm not arguing that those industries do call it OT)

Author: rickbullotta
Content: If it is technology that supports "operations" I think it is.  You could argue that a POS terminal and scanner interact with physical world (people and barcodes on products).  Remember, atoms and people matter too!

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
I am with you on the Scanner. but the people is a bit problematic, as the platform formerly know as Twitter, interact with people (the few that are not bots).
But the supporting operations is key. 
Ithink if it has a direct impact on Operations it is OT. 

If the ERP is down and I cannot add an order, I will probably be able to add it in later and there will be no impact on the plant floor.
with a POS terminal, if it is down, I cannot order now and production is impacted immediately.

But that sort of becomes a spectrum. 
Switch off a PLC, -> Line Stops
Switch off a SCADA/HMI -> Machine might keep running for some minutes, typically there will be some stoppage or failure and you cannot restart
Switch off a MES   ->  Machine might run for a few hours you can probably finish the order, but you might have an issue restarting downtime or managing rejects
Switch off a ERP ->  you can probably keep production going for a day or two. might even stretch to a week.

If the ERP is so tightly integrated that the plant will stop in less than an hour, I would say it has crossed into OT. 

of course you lose functionality, and you might not collect data or information , but that is a sperate question

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
Shock Collar - No
Brain stem sensor make them a Cyborg and Cyborgs are OT

Hi everyone, I'm looking for a historian fitting for my usecase.
I have a beginning OEM that wants to collect data from its machines worldwide.

Ideally it should be: cloudbased, easy to setup & maintain, able to connect to MQTT and/or OPCUA and cheap

Author: douglawrie
Content: Hi all. I‚Äôve got a project where I need to collect and store millions of tags from hundreds of Modbus TCP devices. My current thinking is do the Modbus polling with something like Kepserverx and collect the data to Canary via OPC-UA, though I‚Äôve never used either product‚Ä¶. With such a large number of tags I‚Äôm wondering what is the best way to model and repeat the data hierarchy based on templates. Do I create the tag mapping in big CSVs and import to Kepserver so Canary can auto consume, or do I just present raw modbus addresses as tag names in the OPC server and do the modelling in Canary? What is the most efficient way to do this work given the hundreds/thousands of devices are identical?

Author: douglawrie
Content: I also would need to repeat the Modbus polling settings (especially poll rates for different groups of tags). Is that best done in the OPC server or in Canary?

Author: hobbes1069
Content:
I don't think your idea is a bad approach. For the price, Kepware Server is a good product. I don't have hands on experience with Canary but have heard good things. Since the machine are all the same (or very similar) you can "cut and paste" the tags/devices in Kepware so that helps speed things up but at "millions" of tags some sort of bulk import process would be preferable. 

Poll rate would be set in Kepserver and then I assume Canary has the ability to subscribe to the tags so you could get them "on change".

Author: douglawrie
Content: Thanks Richard. I also assume Canary has a subscribe option but the quick demos I‚Äôve seen use a poll rate? Can any Canary users shed light? Bandwidth may be a concern for me.

Author: hobbes1069
Content:
I found this, were I don't see subscriptions, but it does mention deadbands if that helps:
https://helpcenter.canarylabs.com/t/h7hfzm5/how-to-configure-the-opc-ua-collector-version-21

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Actually deadbands may work better if you know what kind of change the customer is interested in.

Author: ted.garrison

Author: rickbullotta
Content:
Lots of comments...

1) Viewing Things as only properties misses out on a lot of the power and capability of ThingWorx.  A thing is properties, events, services (functions) and subscriptions.  Also, any of these can be attached to Thing Templates as well
2) Mashups can be modularized as well (e.g. mashups can contain other reusable, templated mashups).  As an example, you can create a mashup that is for submersible pumps, in your example, and that can be reused and linked dynamically to any instance. Somewhat like faceplates in the SCADA/HMI world
3) There are "flows" (workflows) but the more valuable stuff is often the subscriptions and services the implement business logic.  ThingWorx is inherentely event driven in this regard.  
4) There can actually be multiple "databases" for ThingWorx.  You can specify different "providers" for different types of data - configuration data, structured data, unstructured/textual data, and time series data (e.g. you can use SQL Server for some stuff and Influx for others)
5) ThingWorx APIs are bi-directional and provide the ability to read and write property data, read and configure metadata/models, read and write historical data and events, execute Thing services, and so on
6) There are extensibility SDKs to let you build custom inbound or outbound connectors and to create custom widgets
7) Without overcomplicating it, there is also a construct called a "Thing Shape" which can add capabilities to Things and Thing Templates.  As an example, if you had thing templates for filling machines, labeling machines, packing machines, and palletizing machines, you could also have a Thing 'shape' for OEE that you could attach to those template to add OEE calculation and visualizations in a much more maintainable way.
8) You probably shouldn't go directly to the database for BI purposes.

Author: ravil1
Content:
Hi,  Dear Community Members!
New version 1.1.0 of the OPC UA Forge ( https://onewayautomation.com/forge) has been released! 

I think this is the tool many community members here are looking for!

To me, it is a perfect WYSIWYG tool to build and run your UNS. Additionally to existing model building and data normalization/harmonization features, now you can not only access data in it via OPC UA REST API, but API is expanded to configure it too. Also, you can also browse the UNS via this API. It has Swagger API documentation, which is very nice too.
Another new feature is that now you can have MQTT data sources, that is, subscribe to MQTT topics not only in Pub/Sub format, but also plain MQTT with JSON  payload format. The same for publishing: payload can be in generic JSON format, or OPC UA Pub/Sub format.  

And one more feature to mention: it can be used as a historian too! Historical data then can be accesed either over OPC UA interface of via REST API. 

Complemented by DevieGateway, you can reach data from almost any industrial device.  We even offer it pre-instaleld in Industrial PC, with remore management / configuration  / access options.

Contact me for more details, for demos, and to download trial version to try it.

Author: amyw0048
Content: Has anyone used both FactoryTalk Batch and Ignition Sepasofts Batch Module, @Dylan DuFresne ? Any strong thoughts on one over the other? My initial leaning is towards sepasoft for the plc vendor independence. Curious if anyone has reasons why you would  want to use the FactoryTalk Batch - assuming the use case is just rockwell plcs atm, with Ignition for SCADA.

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @AmyW, you just advanced to level 6!

Author: _dyland
Content: I haven't really used either myself. After researching them my team ended up building our own in Ignition's SFC module. Sepasoft Batch looked too restrictive for our use case. FactoryTalk Batch was discounted pretty quickly due to not having anything else Rockwell in the stack besides the PLC. In the end the SFCs were very heavily integrated into the custom workflows of Import Recipes (from RMS) -> Create Order(s) -> Create Run(s) -> Schedule Run(s) -> Execute Runs(s).  Updates from each stage were logged to the database as they occurred which enabled some really nice live dashboards and reports. This took it from Bulk ingredient to finished product with the end of one batch potentially being the bulk ingredients of the next until we ended up with a finished product. That said, this was animal feed, there was some FDA stuff but nothing too complicated. I am not sure about the specific requirements of Pharma.

Author: _dyland
Content: This was also intended to be productized and implemented at multiple sites.  So a lot of the development time was accounted for over multiple projects worth of revenue.

Author: _dyland
Content: I would likely do it different today, but I still think I would make something custom.

Author: _dyland
Content:
I also spent over 200 hours just talking with the operators, Maintenance staff, and management in order to understand the existing batching systems and workflow in order to identify the needs. And another 200 touring different facilities that used the existing systems  Which led to the decision to create our own, which in this case resulted in very satisfied customers, successful startups.

That said, most of the existing competition was using custom proprietary SCADA / MES that was developed 10 - 20 years ago... lots of vba, ms access, activeX, and .net. 

No Ignition or FactoryTalk Batch in sight. Except for one, who used Ignition as an HMI and their proprietary system as MES and Batching.

Author: _dyland
Content: The point of these extra details are - Building our own was expensive... and a calculated expense. Buying one can make more sense in a lot of cases.

Author: rutger_18900
Content:
I have not used either of these but have worked with WonderWare InBatch (now AVEVA batch manager) and Siemens Simatic batch.

WonderWare was good, but the latest version I've used is 2014, looked into 2017 which looked mostly the same but not after that.
Not cheap though and I believe they moved to a subscription-only license model from what I've heard.

Simatic batch not my favorite. Only really seemed to work alongside PCS7 and no easy way to configure in bulk. Might have been just me.
Also expensive and a very complex licensing model.

Playing with Sepasoft Batch Procedure module is on my todo list.
I downloaded the demo and it didn't seem to work very well from the get-go for being a demo, but to be fair the other systems I mentioned you CAN'T even just download and try it so I'll cut them some slack üôÇ 
I'll have to invest some time and give it a proper try. I also like the adherence to ISA standards and how open they are with documentation and pricing.
Since I tend to work with Ignition these days, Sepasoft will likely be my go-to recommendation to customers if it holds up, if not with their perspective components then just the DB and the api.

COPA-DATA also has a batch control module that looks good. 
Pricing is in line with sepasoft for unlimited, cheaper options are available as well limited on ISA88 unit count.
I played with it briefly but not in a real project.
It's built on top of their zenon platform so you'll need licenses for that too, similar to needing Ignition for Sepasoft (but here it's the same company).
They have a free trial license and online training so you can try it out for yourself.
https://www.zenon-academy.com/catalog/view/course/id/190/title/zenon%20Batch%20Control

If anyone has other alternatives for a good ISA88 based batch engine, let me know üôÇ

Author: Deleted User
Content: Hi, are there any weight scale devices which support some type of standardized interoperable protocol? Or is it typically serial based communication only?

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I always just used the many free or cheap serial/IP drivers that can publish as OPC/OPCUA/MQTT for stuff like that.  Mettler had some stuff for OPC UA at one point - I don't know if they ever productized it.

Author: _dyland
Content: Depends on exactly what you are looking for and how you define standardized interoperable protocols... Pretty much every manufacturer I have used has a Modbus/TCP option among the less interoperable protocols. Hardy Solutions has some with Webservers for configuration too, which really help with remote support.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content: It's generally easier to use existing/used or buy whatever solution that weighs well and integrate it.  Scales are commodities.  It's trivial to capture a measurement value.  It's usually defining/parsing some ASCII telegram bound by a carriage return and line feed.  It's often faster/cheaper to integrate than research/buy with the ideal connectivity features.  There isn't much value having, say, a Rockwell Automation 'Add-On Profile' to simply read a floating point.  RTA has gateways that make acquiring data from scales, barcode scanners, quality instrumentation, or anything else similar very easy.

Author: diederik9434
Content:
Another day, another product request! üòÑ 

Today I'm looking for a Edge solution that's able to send tags to an MQTT broker in bulk! 
Requirements:
- software solution (no hardware)
- containized/VM deployable
- able to import tags in bulk or browse for them** (import CSV/XML/... file or browse and select node-ids,...)
- protocol support for at least; S7, OPC-UA & MQTT

Nice to haves: 
- centrally managed
- cheap/free
- broader protocol support (OPC-DA, Modbus TCP, ,...)

I hear you think; HiveMQ Edge! well, correct me if i'm wrong but as far as I know each tag has to be handled individually...?

Kind regards,

Author: diederik9434
Content:
Hi everyone!
Has anyone experience pushing OT/automation to good data governance? How do i make sure each sensor/PLC is supplying the same data? I would like to allow the OT engineers to map their data to our standard data models. I know highbyte is super fit for this but i need a cheaper solution. Any suggestions? üôÇ

Author: diederik9434
Content: (so something to do decent DataOps with)

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Call HighByte and explain your needs and your use cases.  Most software companies have flexibility with pricing.

Author: diederik9434
Content: Thanks! Do you know any alternatives for Highbyte? (I know Ignition is also very capable of building datamodels)

Author: trentc
Content: Maybe node-red? Not sure on performance at scale....but it definitely works for data modeling. Combined with flowfuse....you get multi-instance management, development pipelines and revision management.... +++

Author: xamp4248
Content: It is possible with the template and function node in node-red. @Diederik  DM me if you need support.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Actually I‚Äôm unaware of anything in Node-RED that does ‚Äúdata modeling‚Äù.  It‚Äôs pretty much hardcoded into your flows.

Author: trentc
Content:
Maybe I need some clarity on what "data modeling" is under this context? 
Adopt existing or defining new structure, datatype, attributes...normalization...transformation...all of which I believe Node-red has capabilities to do to some degree through JSON and javascript....? 
I understand there are relational and visual components that add value to a data modeling tool....which node-red doesn't inherently have....

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I think we‚Äôre sort of in agreement on the strengths and limitations but not the terminology. I would say that N-R does data transformation.  Modeling is a parallel process that as you suggest would typically have a UI, a repository, and a means for referencing those models in a reusable way.  There are likely some nodes that can import or reference external models such as OPCUA, WOT, DTDL, etc. - but I‚Äôm unaware of any ‚Äúmodeling‚Äù capabilities.

Author: trentc
Content: Templates using mustache templates? You can save them to a library....and recall them...

Author: trentc
Content: You can also store them elsewhere...use a node to put a template in a msg.payload....

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Not really.  I guess Notepad is a data modeling tool if you want to do stuff manually.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Mustache templates don‚Äôt really give you data typing and metadata, which IMO are integral to data modeling.

Author: mck555
Content: @Diederik you can also check out Prosys OPC UA Forge, its core feature allows you to import your own models and map them to underlying data sources either via UI or an import API. You can also PM me if you have any questions regarding it.

Author: lukraj
Content:
Hi all!
Can someone, please,  recommend a Meter-Bus (M-Bus) to mqtt gateway? There are many M-Bus to Modbus TCP converters out there, but wondering if direct publish to mqtt broker option is also possible.

Author: trentc
Content: https://flows.nodered.org/node/node-red-contrib-m-bus

Author: xamp4248
Content:
Node-Red can. If you want an enterprise solution, go to
https://www.adfweb.com/Home/products/MBus_MQTT.asp?frompg=nav13_28

Author: trentc
Content: @Lukasz let me know if you want to go node red route and want some help getting it going.

Author: lukraj
Content: Thanks @trentc - 4.0 Hero LLC, will need to think about it. I have approx. 10 locations to handle with up to 20 slaves each. The TCP option is the only plausible one since I have network cables available at each location. Single instance of Node-Red should handle it, but wondering if it's worth the hassle if there is a gateway that can publish directly to a broker.

Author: trentc
Content: Depends on your perspective and use case. Node red can operate as a simple gateway, for multiple nodes, but if you think you need more, it‚Äôs far more capable than a simple gateway. I would consider where your gateway or node red will reside in your infrastructure, as you don‚Äôt want to use poll and response comms across long network distances and expose your infrastructure to the additional traffic. It‚Äôs more ideal to be on an isolated network in close network proximity and have multiple ‚Äúgateways‚Äù, node red or not.  Is this tcp or serial mbus? That will quickly help you decide on architecture.

Author: trentc
Content: Other things to consider, formatting of the mqtt payload and any possible context that may need to be included, as well as gateway management, what does that workflow look like if you need to make a change, and how easy and efficient is it for the responsible parties to modify.

Author: lukraj
trentc
Content: The node red node mentioned tcp or serial , but i also was wondering how that worked as well. It‚Äôs referring to the adf web converter that you were looking at.

Author: trentc
Content: Because of the hardware requirements, you have to get an interface adapter, as you have already discovered. Either a serial, USB or Ethernet adapter. The most direct option is the adfweb ethernet mqtt option but the most flexible remote management option is to combine an industrial pc and a usb or modbus adapter. Looks like hms networks and carlo gavazzi have one to convert to modbus, for an industrial solution, but it would also require configuration software. Cheapest route is aliexpress, amazon, ebay for a usb adapter and digikey for an edatech industrial raspberry pi with node red. There‚Äôs also the possibility of a low cost PLC with a modbus to mbus adapter.

Author: zack.scriven
Content: Litmus

Author: trentc
Content: Litmus is great for device drivers, which provide normalized, and contextualized format, with tons of tools for handling, pre and post processing of data. But last time I demoed Litmus, any data structure manipulation was done in their embedded node red ‚Äúflows‚Äù. I am excited to see what they have changed since, in the upcoming mastermind call.

Content:
not exactly what you are looking for but I do like theses units which are developed to take pulse outputs from Meters.
I have used them to count pulses for product count, very easy to set up, 
No wifi, but I think you can send a Digital output which could shutoff.
https://www.hw-group.com/device/poseidon2-3268

I have seen people use an Arduino Opta, and connect to the meter vie serial port and then MQTT from there.

Author: lmtx
Content: Is it possible to cut off a specific utility (for example, water) using communication between that unit and the meter?

Author: sparkylarks
Content: how is the utility cut off? you can drive a DO remotely, I believe, but I have not ever implemented it.

Author: lmtx
Content: The business requirement is to stop the water/gas/electricity supply remotely.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
Is the potential customer a Utility?

I know of Utilities who have remote disconnect metering, but they normally are custom built and they order hundreds of thousands.
where you have individual customers, you tend to have bespoke solutions , e.g. PLC reads from meters, publishes to MQTT, and a remote signal that is received from the PLC triggers a DO and that opens and actuator, or shuts a valve.

We are cleaning some global distributor pricing misalignment and publishing it online in the next version of the website. 

Pricing is straightforward- starts at
Foundation -  15k / site / year
Growth - 25k / site / year
Scale - 35k / site / year 

Scales nicely from 1 site to 100s of sites - variable discount %

Author: rutger_18900
Content: Does that mean no limits on amount of edge instances within a site, and no limits within an edge instance?

Author: vatsalshah
Content:
No restrictions on # of instances on the site. Can be deployed on docker, VMs or baremetal.
Generous # of tags included. We usually remove tag restrictions when customers do multi-site scaled up deployments.

Content: Anyone have experience using OPC Router? it seems to be like a dataOps platform.

Author: lopa0679
Content: we have been using opc router for 3 years as our protocol converter / data modelling tool. i would say you should compare it to node red. I really like the way you can organise your "flows" (imo that part of node red is horrible, just let me add folders please) and the web interface in the latest version is a huge improvement but still needs some bug fixing. As long as you can script .net you can also do more complex modelling (like with JS in node red) but I personally feel like they have not put much love into the scripting tools and they have one of the worst documentation i have seen so far.

Author: mariano.beracochea
Content: Im using node red on a POC and just installed OPC Router(the goal was to transfer data from Kepware to MQTT, is cheaper than the IoT Gateway) and found that it can send data directly to influx, make calculation, It seems to have potential and may replace node red for me

Author: lopa0679
Content: Yes, I can confirm that it is possible. Just keep in mind that you have to buy a module for each function (MQTT, scripting, Influx, OPC client,...) Also I would recommend to test the scripting with local variables and create a script to "parse" the results of Influx queries.  But I am still interested in other oppinions as I feel the software has room for improvement.

Content: Hey folks, just received a request to add some visability to some production braiding machines. No internal PLC.  Initially im looking for a low cost HMI setup where operations could start and stop work orders from the machines themselves.  Potentially in the future we would add some monitoring features.  We host an internal UNS in ignition so I plan to publish the next work orders to the HMI and the operators would select the next one at the machine. Something SpB capable would be great but not necessarily needed.  Thanks in advace

Author: ted.garrison
Content: Depends on where you plan to go.  Do you eventaully plan to need to collect signals?  If so, PC would end up being replaced.  If you start with the bare Groov Epic, you can just add the I/O modules over time as your needs expand.

Author: willemrs
Content: Yes to signals but not anytime soon.  Looks like the Groov Epic's got that covered though when we need it.  Looking at the Maple Systems HMI's potentially too

Author: hobbes1069
Content:
Yes, a CMT-SVR would likely do the job. As a headless HMI you would just need a computer (Panel PC?) to show the HMI:
https://www.maplesystems.com/product/modelname/cmt-svrx-820

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Another option may be just using Node Red to create a simple interface. Then you can use something like a Phoenix Contact Web HMI as the interface.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: A groov EPIC is probably the most versatile, but also the most expensive way to go. There's also a newer version of the groov Rio that can run Ignition Edge. You'd have to pay for a license to use it but it would then integrate seamlessly.

Author: rutger_18900
Content:
If I read the question correctly it says multiple machines and cheap UI/HMI, a simple way to start and stop work orders while standing at the machine.

I'd put some cheap hardware by each machine at this stage, depending on what you already have and what the environment is like.
A thin client, a panel PC, a simple tablet fixed at the location.
Or let the operators use their smartphone or tablet where they scan a barcode or nfc tag on the machine (or manual entry) to identify it before they hit start work order, ...
If your Ignition license includes perspective unlimited, I'd use that. Otherwise maybe NodeRed or a small custom app?

Where are these work orders managed? (MES, ERP?) does this system have a web interface you could use directly for this instead?
How do you plan on communicating the selected work order back to this system?
What if 2 machine operators decide to claim the same work order at the same time?

Next if you want it really integrated with the machine and collect data directly from the machine, sure add some PLC's.

Author: willemrs
Content: Thanks for the feedback.  That is correct, really looking to get some user feedback at the machines now.  As for communications we have options but I would like to have these directly publish back to our internal UNS as a bit of a POC.   I'm going to test out a few of the options,  starting with the node red and panel PC or phoenix Web HMI's.  It looks like the cost difference is substantial enough to test that out before we spring for one of the Epic's later on.

Author: trentc
Content:
I don't see why not....but if you just want it in MQTT, kepware has iotgateway as well to publish to mqtt, however the structure/format of the payload is predefined...so you'll have to adapt to that for any consuming application.

Author: aphexddb
Content: Python has bar none, the best ML and data tools available, e.g. numpy, pytorch, scikit, etc. It's the language of choice for ML most places. With those libraries you can trivially do predictions, and build models on data. So if streampipes supported Python natively, it would make it incredibly easy to run code that does sophisticated and realtime data analysis on the shop floor, vs. sending it to a cloud stack somewhere

Author: anibalvelarde
Content:
Hello John P.,
I have started to look into this option.  We are looking for better, budget-friendly, machine monitoring solutions and AWS IoT Greengrass + SiteWise seem to be a good fit.

ATM, I am trying to get a PoC going in our shop and using a Docker container to host a Greengrass device on prem (as a docker container), connect it to our OPC/UA server (KepwareEX6), which is harvesting tags from machines on the plant floor.

The AWS TAM helped me navigate the AWS Service Pricing Calculator and defined a cost picture with one of our plants. We liked it so much (compared to what we already have from different vendor) and it was enough evidence to sink some time into a more formal PoC.

Author: iilaw_25089_30741

@RemusPop LoRaWAN  Sensors have very good indoor propagation (range)

Some have Gateways have node-red so integrating into your infrastructure should be straight forward.
I well positioned gateway can cover a large area and should cope with up to 300+ sensors.
LoRaWAN is only just starting to be deployed in manufacturing but is widely used in building automation and increasing in oil & gas.

Author: moonahe
Content:
I'm looking for a product recommendation or maybe someone to just change my mind. I'm looking for a free alternative to node-red that is not a drag and drop format. Here are my thoughts.
1. A graphic UI for visualization is great, but I feel like it doing change management and history in a low-code tool would be a nightmare compared to code-only. Now I know that node-red has "Projects" and change history built in but managing these changes still feels excessively difficult.
2. Another issue I have with the low-code solutions is the lack of standards for designing solutions. I'm worried I'll have rouge pipelines that no one understands and start breaking things when they get changed.
3. Logging and telemetry data in the pipelines. While we've able to successfully been able to add telemetry data for http requests to node-red it doesn't look like structured logs for JavaScript is supported by Open Telemetry, which is what we are trying to stick to.
We are still early in a I4.0 implementation, so I may be over exaggerating my needs here, and like I said I'm willing to change my mind. So I'm curious if anyone has experience dealing with these issues in a pipelining tool. Because we are still so early in our implementation I don't want to pay for a premium tool until I can prove value. So I'm trying to find free and open-source solutions.

Author: juba5060
Content:
Hey.  Grey here from Flowfuse. While we aren't free, we do cover a lot of what you are looking for and it is still Node-Red.  We elevate Node-Red for the enterprise. 

1. Change management. We have that feature. 
2. I would like to dig into that more to understand. For example we have the ability to lock a Node-Red runtime down so that only an Admin can make changes. RBAC
3. I need a little bit more context. We have APIs for the audit logs of Node-Red and the standard output. 

Lastly, we have a DevOps pipeline that allows for roll out of your applications.

Content:
I would start with asking why the battery requirement? For a few reasons, first if it needs to withstand very cold temperatures a batter is probably going to struggle. I would assume that the Rockwell PLC already has power, is there a reason you can't tie into an existing panel? Author: brianpribe
Content:
So the advice I got for you comes from @Jeff@Flow at Flow Software from their training courses. Predictive analytics is a very difficult problem, because of all of the other problems you have to solve first. It goes as follows:
- Descriptive: Is the "what happened?" 
- Diagnostic: "Why did it happen?"
- Predictive: "What is likely to happen?"
- Prescriptive: "What should be done?"

Before you can get to Predictive, you have to have Descriptive and Diagnostic nailed down. Luckily, 80% of your problems are understanding what happened, and why it happened.

An example is a production line having an unscheduled downtime (descriptive), due to the line running too fast (diagnostic), and will continue doing so for the next week until a specific work order is done (predictive). To complete the work order on schedule and prevent future unscheduled downtimes, we need to slow the line down to the optimal speed (prescriptive).

While there are few options on CMMS platforms, most of them will fall flat if you don't provide the Descriptive and Diagnostic information needed to get Predictive analytics. 

Now I don't really have advice on which CMMS I would recommend (I'll let others do that), the core flaw in every CMMS is the lack of information feeding into it. We are getting better at this with technologies like IO-Link and better tools like NodeRED to help contextualize and transfer the data to where they need to go, but your CMMS will only be as good as the information that you feed into it. So GIGO. Hope this helped üôÇ

Author: jpmac.s
Content: I have an old mirco 1400 that only has serial,  I want to set it up for the home lab. What hardware would you recommend to convert to mqtt or OPC-UA.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I swore MicroLogix 1400 had an ethernet interface. Perhaps not every model.

If you want to simply give the unit an ethernet interface, look into the Real Time Automation 515RTAENI.  You'll be able to connect from many gateway or applications with native AB ethernet drivers for RSLogix500-based devices.  Alternatively, RTA makes gateways that can convert DF1 serial to MQTT or OPC UA.

Author: trentc
Content: I recently had someone ask about his same issue....you can look at the wintek/maple systems CMT-SVR....it's cheaper....but not "cheap".....the cheapest route is to buy something like industrialized raspberrypi similar to what you can get from seeedstudio or edatec. Then write a python script. This industrialized solution can be had for under $200. And if they are within cable distance of each other...you could use 1 for many micrologix.

Might be easier and more flexible  to buy/trade up to a MicroLogix1400 with ethernet.

As mentioned, Maple System cMT series has a DF1 driver. Cheaper than the RTA units and does not require you to host anything.

Author: trentc
Content:
@Josh Mac I don't have experience with implementing those serial to ethernet adapters....but I have a feeling they will be more headache than they are worth.

They aren't designed to do protocol conversion like DF1, so whatever software you use that handles DF1 will have to be able to point to the converter instead of a serial port.

If you choose to use node-red or python....I'm not sure how the DF1 libraries will pass to an ethernet device when it's expecting a serial port, without some extra work.

It looks like software comes with them for windows to create a "virtual" serial port, this would be key to making them work universally, but if you run on something like a raspberrypi....you'd have to find another route.

While I love IO Link, I don't know that I would look for converters to IO Llink from Modbus. At the end of the day you need to get to an IoT protocol to get access to your data. Anyway, just my thoughts right before going to bed. I may have more insights after some coffee (and some more details) tomorrow.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
The economics of TCP/IP Ethernet don't always scale well at a sensor level.  They can require a lot of power and switching infrastructure. Also, the sensors themselves need sufficient compute.

I would reach out to an application engineer at Real Time Automation and IFM (or the vendor for all your existing IO-Link solutions).  Explain your goals and see what your options are.  

RTA has RS-485 gateways that can support as many as 32 devices.  Even if it's not exactly Modbus RTU, I'm sure they can find a way to accommodate your application.  Their units are fairly flexible in interpreting the signals and payloads.

IFM has an 4-20mA transducer adapter for IO-Link Masters.  You could pair this with third-party  conventional analog power sensors.  Don't read too much into the list price.  Request a quote for the desired volume.

Another option that might be worth exploring is Single Pair Ethernet (SPE).  This is sort of becoming a successor of serial fieldbuses in the process industries because it can go long distances, carries power, and is flexible about what is transported over it.  You could go IO-Link or TCP/IP.  This might open up more options in terms of the supporting infrastructure.

Links:
https://www.rtautomation.com/product/460mrsqt/
https://www.ifm.com/us/en/product/DP1213
https://www.single-pair-ethernet.com/en/technology

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
What is the Energy Monitoring device?
Assuming that it is a device with multiple values, i.e. Electricity Meter( I, A,V,kW,KVA, kWh, kVAh) or a steam flow meter( Q,T, P, kW,Kwh,kg) Modbus RTU and Modbus TCP will both work well and be readily available.

If you are measuring Electricity at the distribution board. Modbus RTU works well because you can daisy chain the meters easily. I would prefer installing a switch in the panel and using Modbus TCP, Daisy chaining can obviously result in the loss of multiple meters after a fault in one, and din rail switches are cheap theses days.

I normally brought a steam flow metre( 4-20 and modbus) back to a PLC and performed the calculations at the edge to give me values such as the amount of steam produced in that last, hour, day .....

Looking at IO/link, it does not seam that there is an Electricity meter available from IFM, and if you could get an electricity meter that uses IO-Link, I would suspect that IFM have it.

If it was me, and I have put in hundreds of energy monitoring devices, I would go Modbus TCP( or any Fieldbus Ethernet based protocol), bring the values back to a PLC if you have some processing, or put them on their own VLAN, and bring them back to whatever Platform you will use to histories and analyse them

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
I have put scores of the Schneider PM500 in over the years and they work well. t
Set a Modbus polling rate of 1s and that gives a lot of great information about where the power is being used.
5 to 10 of them @ ‚Ç¨250 each, would give you a really good idea where the electricity is being used throughout a medium sized Plant.

I would normally have used the Power Total over the last x minutes( 15 minutes/hours/week). If you get too granular you can struggle to see the forest for the trees. create a UDT for the Power meter in Ignition, or even Node Red Influx and Grafana and you would be up and running very quickly. 

I have put in power meters costing $5k+ to measure harmonics and disturbances too generally not worth it.

Big Tip: If your Utility Billing Meter is on the other side of the Transformer to your Power meter, allow for up to 10% power loss between the transformer 6%ish and the fact that cheap meter doesn't measure higher harmonics, I have had a lot of customers complain that the meter on their incomer is proving that the utility is overcharging them 10%

https://www.se.com/ie/en/product-range/61281-powerlogic-pm5000/#products

Author: markpitout
Content:
May I also recommend that the the power meter you place at the main LV breaker (ie just below the transformer) have the capability of measuring  harmonics (preferably up to the 31st harmonic). If your plant has many non-linear devices like variable frequency drives, the harmonics can also lead to significant power losses in LV cables and transformers, due to a phenomenon called skin effect. The main indicator here would be Thdi (total harmonic distortion of the current).

I would also recommend having a power meter on the MV side of the trafo (normally the MV switchgear should have such a meter). The delta between MV and main LV power meters will give you an indication of losses accross the transformer and main LV cables.

If the 70 meter cables you mentioned are on the LV side of the trafo, you will absolutely have losses accross those cables at high loads, unless they are signifficantly oversized. 
And as @Mark O'Donovan mentioned, normal full load losses for 2MVA 440V transformers are in the 5% - 6% range. This is by design, to keep the fault current rating  within managable levels (typically below 50kA). The no-load and full load loss parameters are normally stated on the transformer's nameplate, so  should be easy enough to check.

But yeah. You cannot manage what you don't measure. So power meters are a very good start. Then making sure the right data gets collected by SCADA to be correlated with operational/process data is the vital 2nd step.

If you want to get even more serious about monitoring the health of your plant's electrical infrastructure, there is also a range of temperature and humidity sensors that can simply be attached onto cables, busbars and transformers. They use inductive coupling to power their internal electronics, so no need for wiring, and they transmit their data over zigbee to a dataconcentrator. But I would only recommend this as a potential extra step after installing power meters.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
Cable losses are probably not a big thing based on those lengths.
but can I ask, what is the driver for the initiative.

is it just being proactive to find places to cut cost, or is there some specific concern?
What country are you in by the way?
Are the electric furnace, laser marking and induction hardening, powered by the UPS?
Those are three items that would introduce issues into a supply
  - the Electric furnace and the Laser would add to harmonics
  - The induction heating, would skew the power factor, and you may be charged/penalised for low power factor 
What are you making ?
There are 2 x1000A ACB's shown on the UPS supply, are there big loads there 

- The UPS will smooth the harmonics as the power passes through it, but harmonics can still be generated down stream.
- I know I have connected to the API of a WEB application from a smart meter, but if you can account for more than 90% of what the bill says each month allowing 10% for the Transformer loss, cable losses, and some difference due to the utility having a better meter to make sure they catch all the harmonics.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
If you asked me to design and install an electricity monitoring system I would say
Lets take it as an agile approach and add piece by piece , we can change the strategy once we learn but
1- get a decent power meter on the incomer( at the 3200A ACB), and build a dashboard that covers the basic( Power ,Voltage Current, but also the THD( Total harmonic Distortion) and Power Factor
2) See IF I can connect to the UPS and get data,  see if I can connect to the Generators to get the  data( Great if we can if not that is ok too)
3) Pot a power meter on the main loads mentioned, furnace, induction heating, and laser
4) put a power meter on the top of the Raw supply,( if you cant connect to the UPS)
5) Identify other larger loads that might need a dedicated monitoring
6)Then I would look to get lots of cheap, IoT type power meters , you might have to test some, but something you can add to a smaller load, or a distribution panel and get the data back , via Wifi( if available in you plant)

you might spend ‚Ç¨1000 on a meter for the incomer PowerLogic PM5320. and if there are high harmonics you might need to Keep that sort of spec to track harmonics. If not for steps 3&4 you can use a cheaper meter, e.g. PM5100( it has the same Modbus register map as the PM5320 so that wil make life easier)
If you are chasing smaller loads, I would put up with any concerns over with Wi-Fi, to save on the cost and hassle of running cables throughout the plant. I just don't see a three phase Wi-Fi connected power meter I would be comfortable with for the bigger loads

Author: bill_64454_12446
Content: My background is in building automation with a lot of exposure to facilities maintenance. My understanding of power loss is that it's not so much in the length of wire as it is the quality of the connections. Anywhere that you have any type of termination or connection is a potential for loss. There are companies that specialize in using IR cameras to identify losses at switch gear. The only familiarity that I have with power meters is from Veris which is primarily an HVAC controls company but they do have options with RS-485 Modbus or BACnet ( depending on the model ). However those are probably going to cost more than $600 USD. I can also say the amount of difficult to identify issues that I have fixed over the years by just putting a screw driver on every terminal in a piece of equipment is uncountable. I think maintenance of electrical connections is a very overlooked issue.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
Given the equipment you describes( Lasers, Electric furnace, and  induction heaters)  and the size of the breakers in the drawing, I would say you are working in a an environment with a lot of electromagnetic interference. And that might be the issue with the Wifi. So I 100% understand why you would install network cables.

Your plant I suspect, will have loads of harmonics, and significant currents on the neutral and earth cables. so if those are not sized correctly, or terminated correctly or get damages or as @Bill points out, even if there is losses in a cable the point of failure tend to be at the connections, typically when a connection is done poorly, so IR Audits are certainly a good recommendation. If there is significant electrical losses, it shows up as heat so the IR cameras would help.

you might be at risk of currents circulating in shields or amount if they are incorrectly earthed at both ends, but if you have issues with induced currents or any other losses due to electromagnet field, they ultimately show up as heat too.

Author: theober
Content:
Actually important point here, and @Richard Shaw is totally right - focus on what operations you're _actually_ looking to improve is critical. 

I'd argue that Tulip Apps and HMIs have fundamentally different targets. 

The thing that (imo) many HMIs (and automation platforms and MES's, for that matter) tend to leave out is that even if you have an absurdly feature-rich and performant HMI, that consolidates 5,000 tags and includes support for 300 different drivers, at the end of the day, it's still your operator doing the work, still the operator contributing (or costing!) value to the org. Worker UX doesn't just stop at PLC control. 

Now if a user wants to be dispatched to to the machine that most recently completed cleaning from a logbook, be told what to set up based on routing from an ERP, check out media from inventory, track tool usage with machine uptime, _and_ perform a quality check with a scale? _That's_ a job for an integrated operations platform, and that's what Tulip does.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
There was a question someone asked about Hardware for converting EthernetIP to MQTT. 
At the time I was testing the Siemens CC716, which does not connect to to Ethernet IP but might give some value to people here connecting Legacy Siemens Devices. It is not exactly cheap( ‚Ç¨1800) but 

It has 2 Ethernet ports and 1 Profibus(DP Port). you connect the one Port to the Device network and can communicate with multiple Siemens PLC's and Modbus devices, and you can connect DP only devices with the DP Port.

you can then create a set of Data points to read and write tot he PLC's you can export from TIA/Simatic Set 7 and import into the Webportal

you then can connect the Cloud Port and configure it to Publish and Subscribe to Mindsphere, Azure and AWS, or any other MQTT Broker( like the Mosquitto on my Raspberry PI). Or you can set it up as an OPC server too. 

There are a lot of customizations options, and control customising the payloads , triggers, etc

Certainly it seams a much better approach than trying to use the MQTT Client in the PLC ü§Æ 
I don't know at how many tags at what message rate the device would fall over

https://support.industry.siemens.com/cs/pd/1353623?pdti=pi&dl=en&lc=en-IE

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
How long is a piece of string?

I would be thinking about what happens after commissioning.

All three options are pretty viable but.
What can the site maintain?
What is proven for use in cold environments?
How easily can you expand?
How stable is the data comms? Do you need buffering?
What is already on site?

Author: rahulbala
Content:
How easy is it now to get data out of Tulip's internal database into an external application? 

The last time I played with Tulip was summer 2022, so I'm probably not aware of the latest updates. From what I remember, Tulip did not make it easy to query their DB or get data out.

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @Rahul Bala, you just advanced to level 3!

Author: hobbes1069
Content: There are some limitations through the REST API. You can only pull 100 records at a time, so it just depends on your use case.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content: You could use the ‚ÄòUNS Client‚Äô in HighByte. It can automatically detect and decode the protobuf payloads from SparkplugB publishers. You can inspect a broker‚Äôs topic namespace over a web browser and don‚Äôt necessarily need to be on the same network. It works in unlicensed mode.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Out of curiosity, what are the use cases that require more than 100 records? Is this pretty common?

I believe the internal table trigger thing supports aggregate queries. Is this also exposed over the API?

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Yes, aggregations are supported. As far as more than 100 records most often that's because I want to copy the whole table out of Tulip for other consumers such as Power BI. But there are other implications. In our facility an open order report would certainly be >100 records. Hell our MRB (Material Review Board) inventory would be more than 100 campus wide.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: That's one of the reasons I would like more direct support for Tulip in Highbyte, including offsets (not just index) for iterating through a table if needed.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content: This is helpful context. Much appreciated.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: I already do this in Node Red but it's a crazy flow üôÇ

Author: rickbullotta
Content: That‚Äôs ridiculous. Let‚Äôs fix that at operations calling.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Pretty much any machine learning dataset or analytics query?

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Yeah, I totally get that. I thought the 100 row limit was small. I was trying to learn what that interface was intended for vs what users desire.

In the past, I‚Äôve observed cloud (i.e., multi tenant SaaS) apps have different interfaces for different patterns of access. For obvious reasons, they don‚Äôt necessarily allow people to ‚Äúslam‚Äù a production database with open-ended queries. For these types of queries, there are often some sort of replicated reporting database with a database driver or ODATA interface. The other APIs might be used to support querying  current state (e.g., open workflows, active stations, logged in users, today‚Äôs shipments).

Author: hobbes1069

Content: Let‚Äôs fix it.

Their machine monitoring has improved significantly over the years but it's not their bread and butter.

Content:
fwiw too, one thing to note about tulip is that it takes (roughly) the same amount of clicks to make a button that saves things to a Tulip Table, as it does to hit an API instead 

Obviously there's reasons to use batch methods too but just worth keeping in mind; you aren't limited to only pulling from Tables, you could push/pull directly from apps

Author: sptha_27377
Content:
Hi All
We are engineering industrial automation machines. where a custom made software runs on a PC. We like to replace the old IO cards we use inside those PCs with some remote IO, which is attached to the PC using Ethernet. Does anyone have a product recommendation? Dev environment is C# in most cases. It should be an industrial product. Robust, long availability, 24VDC. We also need Analog interfaces (0-10V, 24ma, TC) I was thinking about Beckhoff remote IO with Ethercat or Ethernet/IP. What is your opinion?

Author: bunchofbytes
Content:
Does anyone have experience or recommendations for Inventory Management Software that is friendly with integration? 

I spent some time learning/building one that accomplishes what my client was requesting and I was also able to integrate realtime inventory status into a UNS.

My reflections: I COULD provide this  to my customer BUT I spent 8 hours just on the wireframe. (Django, python, nginx, TLS config.

I learned a lot especially with generation of QR codes, and the reverse proxy and TLS configuration.  I can see how this could get really expensive for my client if I move forward and provide the full implementation/managent/hosting‚Ä¶ especially when there are new feature requests‚Ä¶

After a quick google search, there are many options for a really cheap monthly subscription ($50 or less)

The only unique thing about my solution is that it has an mqtt interface and can provide data to a uns‚Ä¶ idk if this is even the best use of this feature.

I‚Äôm thinking I should just offer to setup and manage a 3rd party solution but also want to get any recommendations from the community here. Thanks in advance!

Author: trentc
Content:
I‚Äôve seen several solutions, Ethernet/ip is probably the most supported for a pc interface but Ethercat still has good support and is blistering fast.

I‚Äôve seen beckhoff and wago as good options for io on either fieldbus, and have lots of similarities, and flexibility.

Yep. The middleware is a bit of python that listens for new PNs in a broker.  When a new PN is created, it grabs the relevant info and triggers an API call to create the part in Cin7. 
I was also working on something to sit between PDM and the broker (as PDM is where new PNs are born) but realized it will be better to create a PDM add-in. Need to work with our CAD admin on that. 
Discussed a bit more over here: https://discord.com/channels/738470295056416930/1291569657911836702/1291569657911836702

Author: hobbes1069
Content:
Looking forward to the next CMTK Firmware... Great device but does have a few quirks. I've got one in production that won't start new docker images but everything I need is running so I'm leaving it alone>

One thing it needs is a better way to handle button type inputs. Because the MQTT messages only publish on the data record interval having a button is useless. Is there another way to capture it? 

The specific application is I used a CMTK in a tank level monitoring solution and chose an IO Link based Patlite andon light which has a buzzer and touch button. My original plan was to start the buzzer when the tank level got too low but I don't have a good way to capture the button input to silience the alarm.

Author: stephenbryant_89711
Content:
The original concept for CMTK didn't include report by exception, unfortunately.

I got around this on mine by installing the NodeRed container and making a flow which subscribed to the sensor data topic and published it again (on another topic), but only if the value was different.  It's about 3 lines of Javascript!

That's a quick hack to make it do what you want.  If you need a little help with NodeRed, let me know.

I'm dragging the CMTK product owner to a TSN plugfest the day after tomorrow, and I shall mention that "report by exception" should be a built-in feature.  I'm pretty sure it's already in the backlog anyway, and the priority just needs tweaking.

BTW, if you're not using an SD-card, I suggest doing so.  The internal space runs out quickly once you install a bunch of containers.

Author: hobbes1069
Content:
Thanks for the follow up!

I'm not to worried about the logging interval since I'm only doing it once a minute which works well for Grafana. But if there was a way to access the button input on event that would be great (OPC UA? Polling with REST?)

I have a 128GB SD card so no issues on space. I think it estimated over 1700 days of data ü§£

Author: dapomeranz
Content: Working with a client who is interested in a machine monitoring platform, but is struggling with the two ends of the spectrum. They have enjoyed products like Amper and MachineMetrics for the simplicity, but are concerned with rigidity and vendor lock in. But on the opposite end of the spectrum, they don't feel they have enough resourcing or funding to commit to Ignition or hosting more open source based options. Is this dichotomy pretty cut and dry? Is their an interesting middle ground? I thought it was an interesting topic.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: And it wouldn't be worth going with Tulip just for machine monitoring...

Author: stephenbryant_89711
Content:
Hi Richard,
If you're using the 2.1 firmware for your CMTK, you can download the OPC UA app from https://doc.cmtk.de/2.1.0/apps/app-store/ and install it using the CMTK's web UI.  That would be a way to get your button event.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: ‚Ä¶unless you plan to move beyond machine monitoring at some point.  Why not avoid having two products of one can  do it? Perhaps a new cheaper price for just machine monitoring for Tulip?

Author: dapomeranz
Content: I think I am just frustrated that all platforms seem to encompass data capture, data transformation, data storage, and data display. I'd like to see things get more modular for non-technical resources.

Author: dapomeranz
Content: Tulip MM is good but the client sees Tulip as too human oriented and is looking for more of a machine/automation focused tool. I told them this is a mistake but leadership is going to leadership.

Author: stephenbryant_89711
Content:
Unfortunately, it needs an SD card image this time around - too much was different to be able to perform an incremental update.

If you're using 1.6, there is an OPC UA already included.  Here's the manual: https://doc.cmtk.de/v1.6/en/opc_ua_server/

Author: hobbes1069
Content: I'll look at both. I have one in production I may leave at 1.6 and one in the Lab I'll definitely upgrade when I have time. Will it automatically recognize the image on the SD card? I didn't see an "upgrade from 1.6" in the manual.

Author: stephenbryant_89711
Content:
If you want to upgrade from SD card, you'll need to flip the hidden switch inside the device (at the back/top) while it's off.  A thin screwdriver should do.  Insert SD.  Power on and wait until the LED goes steady yellow.  Power off.  Revert switch.  Remove SD.  Ready!

IMPORTANT: export all your data first, as the internal storage is reformatted.

Also, the don't just copy the image file onto a formatted SD card - you need to flash it.

Author: trentc
Content:
UMH IFM Iolink magic!

Guys, check out this article from @Jermuk  at UMH
https://learn.umh.app/course/connect-to-ifm-io-link-masters-using-sensorconnect-with-the-unified-namespace-and-benthos-umh/

I tried it out, and immediately after getting the connection going, it recognized my sensors, retrieved the IODD from the internet, interpreted it, and built the JSON payload necessary for the historian....automagically!

only seen this in a configuration tool...

Content:
I've looked hard and cannot find  power meter with MQTT natively. By that I mean a meter with a LCD display etc.

I would broadly recommend two approaches

Opto 22 EMU. 
Simple straightforward. I think about 1k

Or power meter like Schneider  PM 5000 series, has lots of protocol options but go with  Modbus TCP. Connect using an ignition driver about 300 euro.

If you only have 1 or 2 points and don't have a platform like Ignition. I'd go  Opto.

If you have Ignition already and have a lot of meters try that.

Or I have seeen Arduino Opta over RS485  to a modbus meter and published directly to broker. Via wi-fi

Author: serdargokay_27047
Content:
Hello everyone,

There is a company with 15 energy production plants. This company has deployed one Kepware instance at each plant. Using Kepware, they have developed a program in .NET to log data into MSSQL. Additionally, some plants also utilize InfluxDB, but the company is unsure how the data is being sent to Influx. They believe the logging is also done through Kepware. The data is visualized using Grafana.

Since I have experience in MES projects, the company reached out to me. They are dealing with significant confusion. They want to build an architecture that can adapt quickly to upcoming regulations in the energy sector. At the same time, they want their internal teams to handle tasks on the platform independently, without relying on an integrator firm. I agree with their perspective.

I don‚Äôt have much experience in this specific area. Do you think Kepware + Influx + Grafana is sufficient as a solution? Or would Kepware + Ignition + Historian be a better option? (It‚Äôs worth mentioning that Ignition‚Äôs Historian has a bad reputation, although I‚Äôm not sure how the new version performs.) Also, I‚Äôm not entirely sure why Grafana should be replaced with Ignition. The company asks if the platform could allow them to easily create drag-and-drop reports independently, but I‚Äôm skeptical. No matter how simple it is, internal teams often struggle and require consultant support or IT/OT teams to create these reports.

If Ignition is chosen, would it be better to have a single Ignition instance for all 15 energy plants, with Ignition Edge deployed at the plants? Have you had similar experiences in this context? Thank you.

Author: nickn5549
Content:
This is a classic case of starting with tools instead of architecture. The company has accumulated a mix of technologies - Kepware, MSSQL, InfluxDB, and Grafana - without a clear strategy. It's like building 15 different houses and then trying to figure out how to connect them all.
Let's break this down into what they actually need:
First, they need reliable data collection. Kepware is good at this - it's one of the few things in industrial automation that just works. Keep it.
Second, they need a unified data architecture. Right now they're splitting data between MSSQL and InfluxDB, which is asking for trouble. This is where Ignition makes more sense than Grafana. Not because Grafana is bad - it's excellent at visualization - but because Ignition is an industrial platform, not just a visualization tool.
The question about a single Ignition instance versus Edge deployments is really about architecture. With 15 plants, you want a hub-and-spoke model: Edge at each plant feeding into a central Ignition system. This gives you both local autonomy and centralized control.
As for drag-and-drop reports - this is a trap. The promise of "citizen developers" always sounds good, but as the company suspects, it rarely works in practice. What you actually want is a well-designed system that makes it easy for technical people to build what the business needs.
The real solution isn't about picking tools - it's about building the right architecture. Start with a unified namespace, use Edge at the plants for local resilience, and centralize where it makes sense. The tools should serve the architecture, not the other way around.
Remember: architecture is destiny. Get that right, and the tool choices become obvious.

Author: serdargokay_27047
Content:
Thank you very much for your feedback. Every integrator has added something over time, creating a scattered structure. Since the customer wants answers from a trusted source, I am conducting this research for them. Although I made it clear that I haven‚Äôt worked with a structure like this before, they prefer my research because they struggle to find a reliable source. This, naturally, creates some pressure. Your comments are very valuable.

First, I will focus on the architecture.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
Serdar,

@NickN is right, sort out the Architecture first.
and a big thing to understand is how critical is local visualisation in each plant in particular>

I have built similar systems for multiple windfarms and had InTouch at each location, later changed to WinCCOA. Kepware operates locally at each plant, and all the data is collected in a Central PI historian, and then Power BI is used for visualisation tasks 

That was the approach in 2014, and I would not do it the same way. Attached is a conceptual re architecting that I am discussing 

In my case the telecoms connection was not always great so it is important to have local recording, and they also wanted to be able to see the data locally . and they did want to be able to control the switchgear from the site so a SCADA was required, so I would probably  today look at FrameworX on each site, with a MQTT broker and some simple visualisation, then push that to a Cloud Broker, tie it to a Time base historian and then look for some dashboarding software, check out peakboard, maybe if you want to self build.

So Ignition Edge might help you there, and if you  are thinking Ignition then 

What sort of budget are you thinking, My energy clients, will pay to ensure robustness, and infact very preformat open systems are treated sceptically,

If you already have Kepware that is a powerful start, and if you don't need local control, Kepware -> Influx -> Grafana is ok but Grafana is not really great as visualisation and you need to be able to write queries, so self building is out.

I do like Aveva Insights for self building dashboards and reports, and Avava are repositioning their historian to be more stand alone

I would be thinking of having Kepware -> Local Mosquitto, and some buffering 
then a Centra Broker with the new Timebase historian, and  Peakboard, to allow the self build

What sort of concerns have you over Ignitions Historian?

There must absolutely be a structure that keeps the data locally and sends it to the central system. If communication between the central system and a remote factory is interrupted, it should continue logging locally and synchronize the old data once communication is restored.

We already have Power BI and can use it for long-term reporting. I plan to focus on establishing the Edge structure and central architecture. Based on this, I need to decide on the right product. Ignition Edge seems like it could be a good option, but from what I understand, it won‚Äôt meet local reporting needs. This requires more thought.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
Is the Ignition Historian just MSSQL??
