Author: _dyland
Content:
Ignition's Historian Module uses a SQL Database to store the Historical Data - (or flat files if you prefer) Not necessarily MSSQL. Ignition handles all of the functionality around historical data, from creating and partitioning the tables to the built in query functions - GUI Based Bindings and Scripting Functions for example. The data is just in tables though so there are some advanced functions that some integrators have created themselves on top of those tables directly. One Gateway can have multiple "Historians" set up too so if the database disk writes becomes an issue there are ways around that.

Technically, for large High Speed applications, other traditional Industrial Historians have outperformed it. Realistically, most applications are not going to stress it to the point where it becomes noticeable. 5,000 at 500ms that are only logged on exception is probably not a situation where any real performance difference would be noticed... I have used Ignition's Historian on Gateways with nearly half a million tags, with half of them set to be historized, on exception.

One of those built in features that Ignition gives is a window in their tag configuration where you can set the rules for what constitutes an exception, minimum time, maximum time, value based, etc...

If Ignition is in the picture, I struggle to recommend a raw Timeseries database against its Historian - There is just too much added complexity for so little noticeable improvement... I am playing with various options in the home lab but for production, I have no plans to replace it any time soon.

If Ignition is not in the picture, for an industrial application, I would be on TimeBase. For me, I start to look to the Timeseries Databases in more IT centric applications or as part of the stack where IT and OT collide.

Long story short - Ignition's Historian comes with a lot of prebuilt integrations with Ignition, rebuilding those to be as good or better is time consuming, costly, and more that needs to be maintained.

Author: _dyland
Content: Another trick for Ignition, is to use Timescale as the "SQL" database. Disable Ignitions partitioning features, and add the timescale compression to the the table that Ignition creates - Best blend of both worlds - This I have done in production, the benefits have really shown on the query side, as in a reduction in the time it takes to get the data into the screens that someone is looking at.

Author: _dyland
Content: If we are comparing a SQL Database to a Timeseries database the conversation is very different than if we are comparing one of them to a "Process Historian".

Author: _dyland
Content:
Kepware with Telegraf and Influx (or I would use QuestDB myself) is a good choice. 
As is Kepware to TimeBase Historian. 
As is Ignition.

All of these options can collect the data from the OPC-UA server and store it. There are nuances to which is better that depend on your situation, needs and architecture.
All 3 of these options can also work with or without a "Unified Namespace" - again, whether or not you should add one, again, depends.

If you are going with Ignition, there are another half dozen architectures that could work, again which is best depends on the specifics.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Take a deep dive into PI AF. While very mature, it has a ton of features for discerning users in specific verticals (e.g., life sciences, chemicals, pulp & paper, oil & gas, energy). There's also huge ecosystem around it. Employees, vendors, integrations, business processes, etc are deeply tied to it. It has long had extensive out-of-box connectivity. It also deeply tied into DCS workloads and there are a bunch of consuming applications for analysis and optimization. It's also been around forever.

This part of the market isn't really about how historize to tags as cheaply as possible. It's not really about a premium. It's about business processes around hundreds of thousands or even millions of points. It's also about risk, compliance and familiarity. At some point, there is so much inertia and complexity is so high, that it becomes expensive just to evaluate other solutions and figure out how to achieve parity for so many business requirements. For many, PI is more of a set of business processes than a time series technology. This is why alternative historians or time series databases are not likely to easily displace it.

Author: _dyland
Content:
The flip side to this I have seen, as I tend to intentionally stay away from those specific verticals... is that a lot of my clients, the ones who even know what a historian is, assume it's PI or nothing and they can't afford PI so they do nothing.

That's where I have seen Canary in a hard place to sell as they appear to be set up as a PI alternative, Ignition's Historian has traditionally been the option that is good enough to do the job and affordable enough to get in the door. Technically it benchmarks lower than most of the competition. (Again this is set to change with the Power Historian, further complicating things).

Forgetting about the terminology here, this gets historical event data in verticals that really never had access it before. 

As an aside, this is why I am excited about Timebase (@Jeff@Flow) it's that same accessibility argument to a new extreme.

Also, why I have been so careful in these responses not to say that one or the other is the better option because it depends on a million variables that we don't know about @Serdar G√∂kay 's application.

It's what @NickN said, $2.85 a tag is a lot,  and if I'm adding on a second cheaper alternative that could also handle the full load on its own then I really question the value of that $2.85 a tag.

In the absence of a Ignition's Historian it would be a very different story.

Author: dsi_101
Content: Ignition tag historian makes it very hard to do anything outside of ignition.  That is where canary comes in, we have stored procedures that gather information from the historian and populate tables. This would be a nightmare with ignition.  Axiom is a way better trending tool then Ignition trending as well. The excel addin is very powerful too, though history exports could be scripted in ignition it is not built in. There is plenty of benefits to canary, but we have had pushback on pricing of late and that is why timebase couldn't have dropped at a better time. Though early testing of timebase is difficult with ignition, but great as a standalone historian.

Author: _dyland
Content:
Wrapping the built-in Historian Functions in an API with the wedev module makes it easy to use the data outside of Ignition thougn. With only a few hours of development.

Also, not built into the historian but Ignition has built in scripts for excel exports too. 

The middle ground, which costs more but is still cheaper is a gateway that is just the Core license, historian, and Web-Dev to act as the API for other applications to the Historian.

That way you can ingest the data in one gateway and use the pre-built historian functions to share that data with other applications.

Author: jeff_flow
Content:
Best to evaluate any historian solution based on the needs of: 
robustness in logging 
ease of getting data out
flexibility to span multiple platforms
capability of trending tool
cost of management/ownership

You are soooo correct Dylan, there is no 'one size fits all' answer. The best path is to understand today's needs of the operation and forecast future needs over the next 3-5 years.

Author: vikanchira
Content:
@Dylan DuFresne @Serdar G√∂kay I totally forgot. N3uron would be a great value for money solution for this.
Use the following modules:
- N3uron OPC-UA Client - Connecting Kepware to N3uron using OPC-UA
- N3uron Historian - it's based on MongoDB and is quite high performance. It would have no issue with your current scope. It has it's own Historian browser with excel export.
- N3uron Web Vision - If you want to have dashboards.
- N3uron Rest API - Server  - So other system can get the data (both real-time and historical) e.g. Power BI
N3uron License is 720EUR/780USD per module, unlimited tags. So it would be 3-4 licenses 2,340-3,120USA.
This would be a low-code/no-code alternative to the Kepware + Influx + Grafana with a much lower cost than the Kepware + Ignition + tag Historian. If you don't need the power of Ignition Perspective then this is a great option.
N3uron has a free 2-hours trial download  like Ignition https://n3uron.com/downloads-software/ You can request a no question ask 30 days free trial too. https://licenses.n3uron.com/trial/
It just pop into my head. @NickN I would recommend this to you as well to try.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: One problem I'm fighting right now is after following the instruction to update portainer, it can no longer connect to the local environment. I can still manually start up the containers but I can't manage them with Portainer anymore.

Author: mparris
Content: Which style of docker were you targeting from the Portainer documentation? Standalone, swarm, or other?

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Stand alone. I'm on Fedora so technically it's using podman but I have the docker compatibility stuff enabled.

Author: mparris
Content:
Hmm... I've seen in the release notes recent support for podman, but got the sense that it's still early. 

The docket compatibility things.... Is that on the OS side to make podman look like docker, or are those settings on the Portainer side?

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Command line wise they're about 98% compatible. Podman runs containers as a normal user by default, which not all containers like. Part of the compatibility is faking `/var/run/docker.sock`. One of the big differences is that Podman directly spawns containers using SystemD instead of by a service/daemon.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: All that said, when I started the stack it launched just fine and I've done is on several systems, both Fedora and RHEL. The problem only appeared after updating the version of Portainer.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Since I have to run Portainer as root (to access /var/run/docker.sock) all the other containers were also launched as root which should cover access issues for the most part.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Fixed it! I stopped and removed the container and restarted it with the `--privileged`  option which helps with SELinux permissions.

Content:
You're running Fedora with SELinux also?!?

Glutton for punishment üòÅ

Author: ravil1
Content: 500K/sec - is that reads or writes from/to the database? What happened later (500K is for shprter period only), can it continoulsy perform writing 500k values per second?

Author: zeratall
Content: That example is reads/sec and that 500k (which fluxates some) is over a 8 second period. Write performance is much lower (Timebase is optimized for reads), I haven't tested writes at scale. Right now the architecture above is only pushing about 4,500 TVQ/s (80 tags at 60hz), the documentation for Timebase says 25k TVQ/s is the limit on the collector, I'll have to report back once I can push some higher write numbers.

Author: mariano.beracochea
Content: Hello, im looking for switches that got NAT capabilities because i have some systems i cant change the IP and they overlap with other systems. I dont there is no local option for me, so i have to shipped, which are some afforable options for Rail DIN you have used?

Author: varghesejm
Content:
We have configured, supplied, tested I think almost every NAT appliance available from: Moxa, Dynics, Hirschmann, Siemens, Antaira, Fortinet, Cisco, Weidmuller, Helmholz l, Checkpoint, Phoenix Contact, RedLion etc etc. which in large part contributed to this series:

https://www.traceroutellc.com/blog#NothingButNAT

Feel free to DM me for a little more color.

Author: mparris
Content: Which of those were switches with NAT functions included?

Author: varghesejm
Content: @MParris often when people ask me this question they're just wanting NAT appliances and are conflating terms but now that the vendors have joined them in this nonsense if the question really is NAT "switches"....there are certain Cisco IE and Stratix that can perform Layer 2 NAT ü§Æ, you can get Hirschmann Eagle and Moxa EDR variants and Fortinet FortiGates that are multi-port switch/router/firewall combos that are NAT capable. Phoenix Contact also makes a very specific "NAT switch" but unless you're a glutton for german UI config punishment its a difficult recommendation. Generally speaking I would take a "good" NAT appliance ("good" = has all the knobs at the second post in my blog series) and your preferred managed switch as separates all day over shoehorning a combo device with less capable (or frustrating to configure) NAT capabilities.

Author: mparris
Content: Best to keep switches switching and NAT appliances NAT'ing ?

Author: varghesejm
Content: Oh and depending on how many systems and the "typical" solution of needing one NAT appliance per system, we have done a few interesting applications with Fortinet and Weidmuller (links below) where one appliance can service MULTIPLE OVERLAPPING SYSTEMS. It's tough to advise this direction because the config gets accordingly weird but we've had a few use cases where it made sense.

Content: I think the only one from that vendor list that is under 500 (US MRSP anyway) is the Helmholz (Standard or Compact Wall IE) and the Antaira LRX-0200. Author: gilligan128
Content:
Questions: 
- do the lines represent invocation flow, data flow, or something else?
- how does the postgres differ from the historian? Is it for reference data?
- what do the kpi engines do?

Author: zeratall
Content:
1) Data Flow
2) Postgres is persisting traditional relational data (Session Info, Setup Info, Stint Info, Lap Info). Historian persists time series data from sensors measured from cars at high frequency. 
3) the Web front end presents aggregated KPIs to users, instead of recalculating the KPIs at runtime, KPIs are calculated on a scheduled job, and then events are persisted in Postgres with relations back to the session, stint, lap. Its thrown in a cluster because at scale the number of uploaded laps is quite high, but at off hours the number of laps is quite low so I down scale to save on compute cost.

Content: Anyone have any recommendations for collaboration software that integrates well with others? We‚Äôre a Microsoft teams company but it always falls short and everything people end up wanting is always a work around.  Looking for something similar to the UNS via MQTT concept where groups can publish updates to projects and others from different groups can subscribe.  Ideally I‚Äôm looking for something that could integrate with a UNS directly but have not found anything yet.   The idea here would be engineering could post updates to equipment/collaborate in a semi public forum to give more visibility to other interested groups.

On their own they are fine platforms but you still run into the same silo'd data scenario if they are not fully integrated with something else.   I want to essentially tie some of our projects back to the actual infrastructure, that now to a growing degree resides in the UNS.  I know teams has tons of integration capabilities but really wanted to see how other folks were doing this if at all.

Content:
I would look into integrations through Workflows in tools like n8n or Zapier if the goal is to get the data into topics in an MQTT Broker. 

If the goal is to get it into the UNS Jira also has an API you should be able to work with.

Author: _dyland
Content:
Although, further consideration around why the data is needed, what it will be used for, are important prerequisite conversations. I am assuming these have already happened... 

There is a difference in the statement "I want the data in the UNS" and "I want the data to be accessible through [x] so that [y] and maybe [z] can [do something] to solve [specific need]"

Author: willemrs
Content:
Cool thanks, I havent worked with Zapier or N8n.  Il check them out.  
In terms of why the data is needed and what it will be used for is an ongoing conversation.  Essentially since we don't have a standardized digital way of exchanging information other than emails and teams messages.  A few sentence update to a given project is either lost in an email or the requesters end up calling an unnecessary meeting.  
Were on the controls/equipment management side of the house so lots of the projects we do are modifications and upgrades to existing equipment or infrastructure.  Whatever information we end up sharing should be in some way be tied back to the context of our site, which now is best pulled together in the context of our UNS.  So its not that this information even needs to be pushed into the UNS however it should reference the UNS to the degree of the equipment that the work may be about.  That UNS reference doesn't even have to come from the broker directly either since lots of our topic structure is in some way stored in a SQL DB.  Think of it like tagging updates with with metadata like project number, hierarchy location.

Author: willemrs
Content: in terms of your last statement.  I want the data to be accessible any open format, either SQL, API..., with tags to tie that information back to a given project # or asset so that we can be more efficient with our time on the information source side of the equation and allow for that same information to be more easily consumed and queried on the the other.

Author: jamesgresql
Content: Interesting! I'm curious what the killer features of Timebase over just using something like Postgres or Influx are? Is it just the frontend?

Author: zeratall
Content:
@jamesgresql  So, full transparency: today is my last day at NG, and my new role is at Flow. I may be a bit biased, but some things I really liked about Timebase that made it a great fit for my specific use case:

1) Read performance, I persist high-frequency telemetry from race cars, and many of my reports involve a few hundred thousand data points. In the past, I tried using Influx. While the write performance was really strong and InfluxQL is robust (you can do some cool things with relational like queries), it was always too slow for my specific needs. Timebase was the first historian where I could render dashboards directly with acceptable load times (from my testing using the Explorer I was averaging 500k pt/s over a 6 min job)

2) Easy deployment automation, some historians have this, some don‚Äôt, but I really appreciate how straightforward it is to automate Timebase deployments using standard practices. The services support containerization and integrate well with DevOps strategies like GitOps. In my case, I'm looking at automating the deployment of collectors on demand, and Timebase makes this simple with its config-file approach.

3) Simplicity for POCs, timebase has handy features that make it easy to get proofs of concept up and running. For example, the MQTT collector lets you define simple, simple JSON, and complex JSON, which is perfect if you just need to throw data into the historian and start testing right away, or if you have a more complex data structure where you do need to map all the metadata.  https://timebase.flow-software.com/en/knowledge-base/mqtt-collector#Type-1

4) It's fully free, since my web app is a passion project, Timebase being completely free was a huge motivator for me.

That said, there are a few things to keep in mind. Timebase is still early in its development cycle, and while new features are coming out all the time, some standard enterprise capabilities (like AD integration) aren't implemented yet. All of the standard enterprise features you'd expect are on the roadmap.

Author: vikanchira
Content:
Hi @Dylan DuFresne Following up on the Historian - Time Series Database theme. We just faced a request from a customer to find a lower cost alternative to the Ignition Tag Historian that they are using. The main expenses being the AWS RDS storage. A few requirements:
- Has to work with Ignition
- Up to 300k Tags with about 12k tag change per seconds
- Store the data for over 5 years
- Has other method of analysing the data in the historian other than Ignition. (Since Ignition Perspective isn't so great at doing this)

We have though of a few things:
- How to ingest data from Ignition
- Having a good lossless compression that will result in small amount of storage cost
- Being able to get the data for analysis.

Came up with AWS Timestream for InfluxDB (basically InfluxDB) and Timebase as the alternative.
- We can ingest the data to Timebase from OPC-UA and Timestream using MQTT
- Storage should be much smaller and cheaper than RDS
- Both have API and SQL like retrieval.

Adding our current experience to the conversation. What product would you recommend? Our engineer is setting this up to test to report back to the customer so I will be able to add more details later on.

Author: _dyland
Content:
I'll start by saying that I'm definitely not the most qualified to answer this, someone like @RemusPop or @Zach E will probably have much better recommendations for specific products.

As I have an innate distrust of cloud storage... Cloud backups are awesome, cloud hosted distribution is great, fog can be cool - but storing significant amounts of important data solely on someone else's server(s) just doesn't sit right with me. I can't think of a deeper form of vendor lock myself... 

That said, if my goal was the cheapest reliable cloud storage I would have to first know what the criteria was. 

Not just ingestion rates and storage length but also how the data would be accessed... 

From there I would try to identify the various options that meet those requirements and the costs associated. Again - not just the cost of ingestion, but also the cost to store it, and the cost to retrieve it. Even the cost to pull it all out if that were ever needed. 

From there I would evaluate the options and identify their costs. 

Once we have identified a few options, then we would have to determine the risks associated with each and make a choice. 

Other factors would be if we are storing every reading or if the sender is doing any sort of filtering, aggregation, or report by exception. As that may help reduce the costs but also may make the data a lot less useful... 

As far as capabilities, I am sure that most anything can handle 300k tags with 12k changes per second over a 5 year period...

That's really not that many tags in the grand scheme of things, I have sites with twice that running in Ignition's historian with a basic SQLServer on premise managed by their own IT department. For access outside of Ignition, I would just wrap their scripting functions in the Web-Dev module. 

If there is an aversion to the Ignition Historian, I would probably look into Timebase by Flow as they can just hook right up to the tags with their OPC-UA Collector... 

If we are talking about raw Timeseries databases, I think any of the popular ones would do it without any issues, QuestDB and Influx can both connect to the OPC-UA tags with Telegraf so that would make it easier to ingest...

If cost is the issue, it's probably off the table but something like Highbyte could make a good bridge as well if needed. 

Though for cloud storage costs specifically I really don't have any recommendations one way or another. 

I hear a lot about Snowflake, AWS has their options, and all of the time series databases have hosting options to look into... I just haven't done my own research into which options make the most sense for which applications.

Author: r.pop
Content:
Short answer look at snowflake. It has a great mechanism for storing Ignition data over MQTT. 

Ingest into snowflake is cheap, where some critics may talk about cost it‚Äôs usually in accessing the data. 

Snowflake charges by compute used. So significant amount of queries against the data can get expensive. 

For what it‚Äôs worth, there is no cloud data warehouse better suited for manufacturing data than snowflake.

Author: r.pop
Content: For example, our UNS demo for ProveIt cost roughly $200 in snowflake consumption? And that‚Äôs mainly because we‚Äôve been running Cortex Analyst, which is a GenAI agent

Author: vikanchira
Content: Getting data to Snowflake would be Ignition MQTT Transmission -> Ignition MQTT Distribution -> Snowflake | Correct?

Author: rickbullotta
Content: If you had 200 users updating the UX with a 3 or 4 queries each 5 seconds, what would the cost be?  Assume historical data queries of 500-1000 values in the result set per each query.

Author: r.pop
Content:
Ignition -> Transmission -> any MQTT broker that supports spB -> Cirrus Link IoT Bridge for Snowflake -> Snowflake. 

The reason this is incredibly powerful is because the IoT bridge is built to ingest Ignition Data. Meaning it understands the payload, and auto-creates the tables on the backend based on the UDT structure. 

So if you plan your UDTs in Ignition well, the tables on the Snowflake side will match it exactly with 0 effort. 

@Arlen Nipper has a great demo here can walk you through.

Author: r.pop
Content:
Depends how well you write your queries and structure your tables. 

If done correctly, likely you would need an XL warehouse, assuming this is 24 hours, you‚Äôre probably looking at around $750/month 

But I would also say your poorly designed your solution if you have 200 users querying a database 3-4 times every 5 seconds. Snowflake or not.

Author: r.pop
Content:
You can‚Äôt compare Snowflake to the cost of an on-prem database. 

You should ask, what would that example you gave cost in Snowflake vs. DataBricks vs. RDP vs. etc.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Right, but there are a lot of knuckleheads trying to use a cloud datastore as their primary datastore - some even for current state.

Author: r.pop
Content:
This is unfortunately true. 

In my opinion, and why we are so tightly tied to Snowflake, is because they designed it from the OT layer up. 

In January of 2023 I sat in a room with @Arlen Nipper, @Benson Hougland, @Travis Cox and Snowflake, and we talked about what the Snowflake Manufacturing Data cloud should look like. 

In April of that year, they launched it, with full support of OT data types and MQTT SparkplugB, soon to support vanilla MQTT. (In terms of auto-generated tables). 

The other reason it does well I think in manufacturing is that at the end of the day, it‚Äôs SQL and Python. Most of your automation team knows these technologies. If you go the databricks route, good luck training a Controls Engineer how to build out a Databricks pipeline.

Author: vikanchira
Content: IoT bridge for Snowflake would add quite a bit of cost though. Making it not quite an economical solution. ü§î

Author: r.pop
Content: It‚Äôs $900/month per enterprise

Author: r.pop
Content: What budget are you trying to stay in ?

Author: vikanchira
Content:
I'm looking to have a lower budget than 1 year provisioned Ignition Tag Historian cost. 
- 500 value changes per second for Ignition is about 3TB disk space/year and 2,500 is about 7TB disk space per year
- Require PostgreSQL RDS single AZ with 4 Cores and 8GB memory instance so this is between db.m6g.large and db.m6g.xlarge
- RDS cost would be from 806-1,210USD per month
- IoT Bridge for Snowflake alone would be 963+ USD per month
- Additional Snowflake cost

Going with Timestream, Timebase, or N3uron would be quite a bit lower cost.

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
It's certainly not an equivalent to the previous Influx, but it's not intended to be either.
Influx core open source has been re-named as a 'recent data' engine. It's purpose to to turn streams of data into parquet files which can then be read by data lakes.
The problem is, iceberg and delta-lake have shifted the game in the time it took Influx to get v3 working.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Or to sync to a cloud Influx instance easily. It also has some significant performance tweaks  as makes it much easier and performant to query most recent values. I heard there would also be a paid ‚Äúedge‚Äù version at some point. What have you heard?

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
I've been playing with the OSS Influx core today. It's still very alpha.
There is a paid version that can be self hosted.
And last-value queries are not exactly fast, around 10ms

Author: rickbullotta
Content: So it's actually super interesting - you can query multiple values in a single query and you can even query a hierarchy or subhierarchy of last_value()s based on the structure of your tag(s) in your influx tables (versus field/sensor/time values).  That could mirror ISA95 if you wanted.  In that case, the latency would still be 5-10ms but you could get a large number of values very efficiently.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
For process-engineer friendly time series analysis, Seeq is nice. 

For more conventional BI with tabular data, I think Sigma has a compelling offering. First, I like the spreadsheet like interface for users to build reports and refine curated views. One of the common challenges I've seen with BI at scale is that users, at all technical levels, want some capability to interact and further curate the data. This often leads to the less-technical users or those with less control over the BI platform/strategy using BI as a data acquisition tool to rebuild what they want in their own tools or Excel. Empowering data constituents is really important. 

Second, I like how Sigma puts the data warehouse to use. The other issue I've seen with BI tools at scale is figuring out where in the stack additional refinement happens. Some orgs rightfully try to get this right in the warehouse, but there is an endless backlog for data engineers and BI analysts to work on views. Some try to avoid bottlenecks and lean on the BI layer. This often leads to suboptimal use of compute. BI owners will find themselves unraveling latency issues, timeouts, inefficient transforms, governance issues, etc. For example, users will try to tabulate large datasets in the presentation layer rather than using the warehouse to perform aggregate calculations and other heavy lifting. And, finally, some will put an ETL or conditioning solution like Alteryx in the middle. I've seen this work, but it requires some foresight and planning.

Sigma, when paired with a good data warehouse like Snowflake, reminds me a bit how Periscope Data was evolving before it peat out after the Sisense acquisition years ago. Periscope figured out how to tap into the performance of Redshift without the hassle of managing it. It broke down the silos between presentation and warehouse. The R and Python options introduced later unlocked a lot of capabilities. Sigma has accomplished much of this but with an easier UX for more users.

Author: antonmelander
Content: Thanks a lot for this. So for smaller companies without data eng/ data science - what would you recommend? Excel?

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I actually recommended both of these solutions because they allow non-technical users to do the most.

If an org has a lot of historian data, Seeq makes it easy for non-technical users to work with time series data. If the data is tabular, Sigma has spreadsheet-like interface for staging datasets for reports.

I do think it‚Äôs important to eventually consider a data warehouse (could be a standard database). Users will eventually want to create KPIs over time. OEE and Gross Margin, for example, require summing and dividing a ton of records. The datasets will get really large and the underlying data may need to be revised or will be late arriving (e.g., misclassified downtime, change/consolidation of master data, returned shipment / refund). It quickly becomes inefficient or impossible to do this within a BI tool. Even at a small manufacturer,  it does not take much for users to run into limitations of a BI tool. Manufacturers generate a lot of data.  A warehouse does requires some technical capabilities but it has gotten considerable easier in recent years. Someone with some experience working with databases can learn quickly. To get started, it can make sense to adopt existing investments IT may have with a cloud provider (AWS, MS). Snowflake is nice because it‚Äôs pretty easy to use and is abstracts the complexity of managing/sizing the underlying infrastructure. If there‚Äôs absolutely nothing, experiment with a database first. Understanding how to build efficient queries for BI is what‚Äôs ultimately important.

If a small company has nothing and is just getting into reporting, Power BI is easy to get started. Most orgs already have M365 and, in some cases, already have it licensed (e.g., E5).

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Greater pricing and trial accessibility is nice, of course. It's a commitment and can take considerable resources to figure out. While it's a better experience for prospects and consultants doing research, it may not necessarily be a priority for those most likely to buy. For example, prospects can see the cost of licensing Power BI. It does not include the support or expertise to be successful. They might need to look into Azure Synapse and consultants/employees to meet their desired outcomes. Instead of trying to cater to "tire kickers" who want to compare price, a smaller company like Sigma might seek out more motivated and educated buyers. That buyer might be more concerned with overall TCO (not just licensing cost) and specific functionality. With finite resources, sometimes it can be a best use of resources to simply qualify prospects and provide them access to technical teams. Ultimately, our expectations as consumers on what is convenient is not necessarily relevant for businesses with pressing, complex problems to solve.

If I were a customer of an SI, I would want the SI to educate me about all solutions and which best meets my needs. I would not be concerned with how easy or difficult they felt it was to research products through google searches. I would want to tap into their vast knowledge, experience, and networks. I would also want them to be aware of the nuances of AWS marketplace (e.g., CPQ limitations, contracts, public offers) and that most enterprise software on it is transacted through private offers.

I discussed the importance of empowering less-technical users and the role of data warehouses for successful BI. John raised great points that solutions with statistical rigor can yield a lot of value. It sounds like you have a great opportunity to further educate the community. Evaluating the features and TCO of various data visualization and analysis solutions would be a great post.

Author: vikanchira
Content:
That might work fine in Europe or the U.S., but a further area like Southeast Asia, getting access to a software solution is a whole different game. The problem isn‚Äôt just cost‚Äîit‚Äôs how approachable the product is.

I‚Äôve lost count of how many times I‚Äôve had to take a meeting in my pajamas at weird hours just to get past the first step of evaluating software. And that‚Äôs me‚Äîsomeone who‚Äôs motivated and knows what to ask for. A less motivated end-user? They‚Äôll just assume the product is too much hassle and move on.

Sure, good documentation, email support, and a self-service trial can help, but if there‚Äôs no local sales office, having a free trial and transparent pricing is absolutely necessary. Otherwise, people will assume they won‚Äôt get the support they need.

And let‚Äôs be real‚Äîsome big vendors with offices here just say, "Trust us, we‚Äôre [big name]," then show a couple of PowerPoint slides and a promo video. That‚Äôs not convincing. The easiest way to win over customers here? Let them try the product without jumping through hoops. Trial is the way.

Author: vikanchira
Content:
I would love to educate the community more on BI and Time series analysis but getting hold of trial demo is pretty hard in this area. 

In fact, I have just drafted a Sandbox fund on our AWS Partner account to try Canary, Timebase, Flow, Timestream for InfluxDB as well as seeing if Quicksight would work with Timestream. Would be happy to share the findings.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: IMO vendors should be selective with free trials - a lot of prospects will not make the necessary commitment to truly evaluate the technology, will not commit resources to learning/training materials, don't really have any plans to buy, and so on.  There are some cases where a low-touch, free eval approach works, but for anything with an implementation scope of significance, I think it's often a bad approach.  I  think vendors instead should have sandboxes set up with a couple use cases scenarios, simulated data sources, and in depth tutorials/education.

Author: vikanchira
Content:
Yeah, it really depends on the target audience. With their enterprise pricing, Seeq and Sigma are probably focused on customers close to their sales team or strong partners‚Äîwhich is a different crowd from what I usually deal with.

That makes sense, but if they aren‚Äôt putting resources into a region, they‚Äôre just not going to be an option for most people there. I think a sandbox with pre-built scenarios and tutorials like you said could be a great middle ground that helps serious buyers get hands-on without requiring a full trial.

Although, it‚Äôs not just end-users who need resources‚Äîpartners and internal champions (the ones actually driving the implementation) need support too. BI and time series analysis is a big space and I have been constantly looking for options for manufacturing. Both Seeq and Sigma looks interesting but it would require a lot of effort in my part before I can even consider to suggest it to my customer üòì

Author: .killnine
Content:
I'm sure it's up to the vendor to determine their tolerance for 'casual' trial folks. But if getting customers is like a funnel, I'm not sure why it's worth making that funnel smaller arbitrarily if your tooling allows users to help themselves and it doesn't drain your resources to keep that avenue open. 

I'm dealing with this with Litmus right now. 

Their docker container is behind authenticated repository. You have to sign up for an account, to then use their store, to make a fake 'purchase' of their trial product to try for 15 days. But after checking out, you have to wait for a real-life person to approve the purchase so you can use it. Like, what?

Compare that to Ignition, which I can just spin up in a container for a few hours to screw around with and test out so I don't embarass myself on a sales call.

Author: donpancoe
Content:
I will have to check out this update, but based on brief evaluation of earlier ThingsBoard releases vs Inductive Automation Ignition...

Ignition benefits greatly from having the tag provider and the HMI elements within the same platform, such that you can add elements to the HMI and instantly bind them to tag values that you just picked from a list. No need to write Javascript (unless you want to), complex REST calls (that you have to test in Postman separately) or Remote Process Calls (RPC). Simply: "when I click this ON button, the value of the tag *IS_ON* toggles from false to true.

Based on earlier versions of ThingsBoard, I've felt that the extra time it would take me to set up an HMI versus Ignition would easily offset the price of an Ignition Edge Panel license (currently $1,850). Maybe that's just because I'm already so familiar with Ignition (Core Certified), but I would seriously consider using ThingsBoard more if someone could show me how to develop in it as quickly as I can in Ignition.

Author: _dyland
Content:
Only know about Thingsboard what I just read on their website and the GitHub repo - But for me, it looks like it would struggle to compete at anything above the cheapest free software stacks? 

Their definition of devices is basically MicroControllers, nothing industrial shows up on their site at all. Which makes sense as they appear to be branding it as an IoT platform not an IIoT one. 

It looks like if I wanted to use it in an industrial space I would still need Kepware, Ignition, or some gateway to convert field protocols to MQTT or OPC-UA. Basically cutting it out as an option as an HMI, which is fine. But it adds in the cost of these gateways to the overall deployment.  Unless it's part of a Node-Red based stack? 

I guess this is the long way to ask @vikan is Thingsboard and IoT or an IIoT platform? From what I see it looks like an IoT. Not Industrial. 

Though that doesn't mean it wouldn't have its place in an IIoT stack. I'll have to look deeper.

We did these visual over 3 years ago in a much older version. A lot has gotten better. It's a flow base type of programming, similar to Node-RED.
Give it a try. From your impression, I'm sure that you will be surprised.

Author: donpancoe
Content:
I think there is a gap in the free-option or "community edition" market (if it is "free" is it technically a market?) specifically in the GUI / HMI space. There are free dashboards aplenty, but few other than Node-RED can easily send outbound controls. I was hoping ThingsBoard could be a contender in that space, but it would be better if they had an internal tag provider like Ignition, even if those tags have to be translated to a different tag provider on a different platform in the end. But the speed of building an HMI is compromised when each new object placed on the HMI screen has to develop a custom script (even if, or especially if it's a script that has to be built on the device end to respond to the RPC from the HMI).

I'm not trying to bash ThingsBoard here, but rather suggesting some architecture changes that I would hope makes it easier to use, at least for my needs.

Author: donpancoe
Content: I'm thinking more about this: maintain a list of "tags" in the HMI platform, it could even be extracted from a UNS. An object placed in the HMI screen could be bound to one or more of those tags, and executing (clicking, sliding, turning etc.) that object on the HMI sends an MQTT message on a topic derived from the tag name with the new value. Or on a generalized topic based on the targeted device with a simple JSON message like {"tag_name": "new_value"}.

Author: vikanchira
Content:
Definitely agree about the tag providers. Having it would help a lot.

If Ignition has a flow based programming features like that of Node-RED and Thingsboard, that would be good as well. We normally hack this using the Alarm Notification

Author: dawd

Author: serdargokay_27047
Content: It is widely used in the iron and steel industry in Turkey. I came across it in a project and really enjoyed working with it. The historian feature had an interesting capability: it could publish previously collected data as OPC UA with the same values. You could speed up or slow down the playback. This allowed us to record everything that happened during a shift and replay it later. It was a great way to test the mistakes we made in the program. I really liked it at the time, but I haven‚Äôt come across it much since then. Of course, other historians might have this feature too ‚Äî I might just not be aware of it.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I have not done a deep dive on Safetychain. My understanding is that they're focused on F&B and provide some out-of-box functionality for processes subject to compliance and auditing. The target buyer are quality teams that need tooling or business processes to adopt. The cost of designing and implementing a QMS (the business processes, not the software per se) can be very high. For many companies, they lack the personnel to do this from scratch. They look look to consultants and off-the-shelf software to get there.

I'm sometimes skeptical when SCADA developers and SIs claim they can build things in Ignition or other platforms cheaper. Yes, I'm sure there exist conditions where that is true. Yes, it's possible to develop a better set of screens and bind them to a database to target a lower acquisition cost. But, what's the total cost of ownership? More importantly, does it actually solve the industry requirements? Who is managing and verifying all the requirements? Who is paying for their time? Has this solutuion actually gotten through a third-party audit? Can line-of-business users who are not technologists "own" this solution and manage evolving requirements going forward?

There's a tax compliance software called Avalara. It's super useful for manufacturers that do business globally. It automatically figures out all the different local tax implications (e.g., sales tax, VAT, customs, filing) for A/R processes at the time of shipment. I'm sure someone could configure/customize their ERP to do this, but understanding all the requirements and keeping them up to date would be challenging. A solution like Avalara is not bought as software per se, but as a business process. The pricing of the software does not matter relative what it would take to develop a substitute. It's the business process and its cost is what matters. It's a repeatable, undifferentiated business process that can be automated and outsourced by a competent vendor with domain expertise.

Author: farid1623

It's the annual nature of the cost that kills me.  Yes a SI is costly if you can't built it in house (we probably could).  But it's a one time cost. With pre-made software you're inherently paying for a myriad of features that your buisness may not have a use for.

Case and point, safetychain tries to advertise that it can provide OEE.  OEE should not come from a QMS...  and I certainly don't trust some software integrators who spend a few weeks at the facility to built an OEE model worth anything.

Author: _dyland
Content:
I'll be honest and say, I haven't gotten deep into Dashboard 2.0 in a while - It was still pretty new when I was heavily in it... And personally, I wouldn't expect you to want to go so deep into the Frontend Development field. 
Also I tend to be an outlier, so probably not the best case study...

But in Node Red in general, even dashboard 1.0, the nodes always feel pretty clunky and require a lot of work arounds and scripting to get right. To the point that I like to do the front end in a platform that is not Flow Based.
Node Red for me is at it's best as a backend Integration Layer.

Say, Connecting to PLCs and Databases and exposing their data through a REST or GraphQL API. Doing the Front End in say Appsmith or Grafana. My distaste of Grafana aside...

For me, If FlowFuse was to be the Front End, I would really want a drag and drop interface separate from the Flows. Not dissimilar to Appsmith, Ignition Perspective, or more ideally Figma.

Though, as I said, I don't think I represent the full market here... I tend to prefer either Full Code or No Code for UI/UX - Most things in the middle are incredibly frustrating to work with.
Node Red Dashboard 2.0 and Appsmith are among the better ones that I know. Though I haven't gotten any time on Retool..

Simply put, I see Node-Red as a middle layer, flow based logic, Connectivity, ETL, and the like. 
Been using it for over 5 years now and love it where it fits.

Author: .discrete
Content:
I'm a Grafana fan, but there are definitely things I like and things I don't. I like Superset too, but there are little things here and there (like making a string turn green or red based upon value) that I can't do or can't figure out how to do in Superset. I give Grafana the edge but only by a little.

I'm less interested in what you don't like about Grafana and more interested in what you prefer instead and why.

Author: _dyland
Content: For me the big issue is that I can never seem to make, and have never seen, a dashboard made with Grafana that doesnt look cheap and unpolished. It has a very distinctive look and feel that turns me away. Basically any Bi tool that I know of does better in that regard. That said, for simple internal trends for technical teams its fine... For more transactional data I prefer tools like Appsmith, for specifically Bi Dashboards basically any competitor that is a paid platform is leagues better. That said, I use Grafana for some stuff, like simple timeseries charts, I just do do begrudgingly. Ill have to look into Superset, thats a new one on my radar... Looks promising as an alternative to what I do use Grafana for.

Author: .discrete
Content:
If Power BI is heavy semantic model and Grafana is zero semantic model, Superset is light semantic model. That's really the significant difference that impacted my experience.

If you consider something like
https://play.grafana.org/d/000000016/time-series-graphs?orgId=1&from=now-1h&to=now&timezone=browser
or
https://play.grafana.org/d/ktMs4D6Mk/bar-charts-and-pie-charts?orgId=1&from=now-6h&to=now&timezone=utc
or
https://play.grafana.org/d/Zb3f4veGk/stats?orgId=1&from=now-6h&to=now&timezone=utc
or
https://play.grafana.org/d/U_bZIMRMk/table-panel-showcase?orgId=1&from=now-6h&to=now&timezone=utc
...*cheap and unpolished*, then maybe my standards are too low üòâ

I don't think Superset is significantly different from a graphical perspective.

Author: .discrete
Content: Superset *can* paginate things better for printing if that's important. Grafana I believe (fairly) requires the enterprise version for that.

Author: _dyland
Content:
Yeah, the "Cheap and Unpolished" look is in the typography, the font sizes, the way that the text overlaps the charts, the styling of the cards against the background, The specific color pallet that it shoe horns. It makes it all look very technical and leads to a less inviting experience to non technical people. It has a technical vibe to it. 

From the screenshots I can see, the softer pallet, typography, and card borders in superset is closer to what I would prefer but the big thing is the ability to change it to fit a specific audience.

Those are among the better Grafana Dashboards I have seen... Most are no where near that clean.

Author: _dyland

Author: _dyland
Content:
Very doable in Ignition... The big thing to get right is the database schema, the logic layer is the easiest Part. 

I have done it for other verticals, specifically feed and grain. With Thousands of recipes stored and created, orders entered, and runs scheduled off the orders. Ran through the batching controllers and tracked. Though, like anything custom, the risk is in scale and ownership.

The technical side of it is by far the easiest. Even at scale. It's getting all the pieces in play to make it and coordinating the right partners. 

Build vs buy is a big debate here, and there is the middle ground as well. Integrating the bought option is not always trivial... Some i.wlrked with were basically just xml exports that we had to build a database around.

I have also seen systems that are 80% what is needed built custom in .NET apps by integrators that are unresponsive and unavailable.

If you build, be prepared for a relatively large discovery phase. 

If you buy, be prepared for custom integration.

Been down this path, there is no one right answer.

Author: _dyland
Content: Beware integrator and vendor lock either way.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
In general, my vote would be Sigma for overall BI and Seeq for time series analysis. Sigma is "extraction-less" and provides a self-service spreadsheet-like interface. It leans on the warehouse to transform and calculate the data. Some of the modern data platforms like Snowflake, for example, have gotten good for creating time series oriented data products. Orgs are starting to have luck materializing operational time series data into tabular data sets that are easy for line-of-business users to work with. I wouldn't overlook traditional relational BI - especially for the the batch, MES, ERP, etc data. Figuring out some common ways users will query/analyze the data and designing a schema around those requirements can go a long way. Seeq is great for time series analysis. It's very process engineer friendly for ad-hoc and exploration. Eventually, you'll probably want to formalize this into mainline reports either in Seeq or in your BI layer. Seeq has a ADX connector.

Azure Data Explorer (ADX), being KQL-based, might limit your options in terms of BI. There are database drivers that the KQL can be passed through to return data sets, but any of the drag-and-drop tools in BI tools that generate or bind to SQL queries might be an issue. Power BI is an obvious option with its native support for ADX. It's a question of  how productive business users can be working with time series data in it. It might be too raw or the tooling (e.g., DAX, M) might not be enough or too hard to work with. 

Yeah, that's a common complaint about Grafana. It's meant to observe infrastructure. Manufacturing is so much more dynamic where the thing you're observing is influenced by supply chain, batch/lot/inventory, operator, tooling, maintenance, environmental factors, etc. The what-if scenarios can become so complex so quickly. If you're still interested in checking it out, it appears Grafana has an ADX plugin.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Yeah, not a great title for a blog and misleading.

To clarify, modern warehouses are not a replacement for operational time series databases, but have gotten good at warehousing time series data for analytics. ConocoPhillips, Toyota, Lindt, and others are seeing success with this model.

Dumping telemetry to a time series database can be useful for the person intimately familiar the automation producing it. Materializing that data into a curated data sets can make that data more accessible for more people to solve more problems with less resources.

Author: slamber12
Content: Can you expand a bit on this? We are using the UNS to ingest timeseries data (source is historian) and add context to it so it is easier to navigate, it‚Äôs not much different than what Aveva PI gives you with asset framework but all our data will end up in an ADX table. I‚Äôve been able to create a stupidly simple ADX dashboard that any business user could click and plot the tags of interest just by knowing what process area or unit the data belongs to. We have a curated set of tags which have harmonized names like ‚Äútemperature‚Äù that can be compared across similar units. Only thing missing right now is procedural context but that‚Äôs phase 2. Maybe because I was a production engineer I don‚Äôt understand what challenges the business might face with this approach, but to me it feels like we try to over build for a presumption that a business user doesn‚Äôt know what the data is. I want to give that process engineer the tools to be able to support their business line in a consistent and repeatable way so if one site wants something we can offer all the sites the same/similar toolset

Author: slamber12
Content: My business users are mostly data scientists anyways who want to dump the data into python üòÇ

Author: andybmac
Content: Sounds very similar to my clients (and as we're both in life science then not too surprising!) Its that procedural context that is the key - and that seems to be where OSI PI still wins: EF + AF means you can harmonise across units and phases/operations rather than just "tag 1 between t1 and t2".  From the systems I've been looking at (not too deeply yet) nothign seems to quite repalce OSI PI... yet.  Although the costs for all other systems seem to be an order of magnitude lower!  Getting UNS data into timescale (influxdb) is very easy, once you navigate AWS oddities, but adding in the EF so far seems to require lots of lambda functions which is not an OT skill set - to my clients at least.(And yes - we should catch up with a call soon! @Slamber !)

Author: slamber12

Author: expi3pi
Content:
[commercial warning] If you're willing to try something out as a possible extention or replacement for IP21, Factry is trying to match the strength of the PI AF, but by using opensource databases (Influx+Postgres). We then use a custom datasource plugin in Grafana so you can use the asset tree and understandable property names to query the data. We recently released a trial docker stack you can download:
https://github.com/factrylabs/historian

This way you could do a lot of the contextualisation in the historian already, while still being able to easily publish everything over MQTT to Azure.

Author: glennfernandes_80780
Content:
I figured out how to replicate Walker‚Äôs 10 minute sprints!

AWS Kiro ‚Üí zhsama/claude-sub-agent ‚Üí TestSprite 2.0 MCP
Autonomous Development Loop:
Spec: Kiro generates living PRDs that auto-evolve with code changes
Build: Parallel claude-sub-agents (analyst‚Üíarchitect‚Üíplanner‚Üídeveloper‚Üítester‚Üíreviewer‚Üívalidator) handle end-to-end implementation
Test: TestSprite reads PRD or infers from code to auto-test

Human Quality Gates: Configurable checkpoints (planning/review/validation).
Result: True autonomous development with zero manual handoffs via MCP integration‚Äîeach agent builds upon the previous agent's work while preserving quality control.

Production-ready Autonomous Stack
AWS Kiro¬†‚Üí¬†claude-sub-agents¬†(analyst ‚Üí architect ‚Üí planner ‚Üí developer ‚Üí tester ‚Üí reviewer ‚Üí validator) ‚Üí¬†TestSprite MCP¬†‚Üí¬†Terraform MCP¬†‚Üí¬†Grafana MCP¬†‚Üí¬†Docker MCP Gateway

Author: glennfernandes_80780
Content:
SPEC-DRIVEN DEVELOPMENT AS "GITOPS FOR CODE"

Core Concept: Spec-Driven Development with Testsprite 2.0 MCP is to application behavior what GitOps is to infrastructure deployment - both provide declarative, continuous, drift-free delivery pipelines.
Key Difference:
GitOps solved deployment (code ‚Üí running infrastructure)
Spec-Driven Development solves development itself (requirements ‚Üí tested code)
How It Works:
Write behavioral specs (not YAML manifests)
MCP server auto-generates tests and scaffolded code
Claude 4 iterates on implementation until all tests pass
Promotes artifacts to production with same reliability as GitOps
THE ULTIMATE VISION: SPEC-TO-PRODUCTION PIPELINE

Today: Two separate pipelines (Development + Deployment)
Tomorrow: Single business spec auto-generates BOTH application code AND Kubernetes manifests

We're witnessing the evolution from Infrastructure as Code to Infrastructure as Intent - where production systems emerge automatically from business requirements rather than manual configuration. Long live SaaS!

Author: glennfernandes_80780
Content:
Claude Code Sub-Agents & the ‚ÄúBMAD‚Äù Workflow

Concept:
A Sub-Agent is a lightweight Claude worker spun up on demand to handle a single, well-scoped task.
Multiple Sub-Agents run in parallel; the parent Claude instance coordinates their outputs.
BMAD (simplified):
Break the problem into atomic tasks.
Map each task to a Sub-Agent prompt & tool set.
Aggregate all Sub-Agent answers.
Decide/Deploy: parent agent merges results, returns final answer or calls next steps.
Repo quick-start (github.com/zhsama/claude-sub-agent)
agent_parent.py ‚Äì sample controller showing BMAD loop.
sub_agent.py ‚Äì wrapper that launches a Claude chat with a task-specific system prompt.
tasks/ ‚Äì ready-made task definitions you can copy or extend.
run_demo.sh ‚Äì spins up three parallel Sub-Agents, aggregates, prints combined output.
Try it in 5 steps
git clone https://github.com/zhsama/claude-sub-agent
Put your Claude API key in .env.
Edit tasks/*.json to match your problem slices.
python agent_parent.py ‚Äì watch Sub-Agents spawn, solve, merge.
Tune prompts or add tools; iterate.
Why care:
Parallelism ‚áí big latency wins.
Scoped prompts ‚áí higher relevancy, less hallucination.
Save money in API tokens ‚áí smaller focused prompts cost less than one massive context window.
BMAD loop keeps everything deterministic and auditable

Why sub-agents save token costs:
Smaller prompts = fewer input tokens per request
No context bloat = each sub-agent only gets relevant context, not everything
Model flexibility = use cheaper models (Haiku) for simple tasks, Sonnet/Opus only when needed
Higher success rates = fewer expensive retries from failed complex prompts
Parallel efficiency = pay for what you actually process, not one giant sequential prompt

Start small (3-4 tasks), measure speed/quality, then scale out. 10 minute sprints for the masses ‚Äî Counting down to ProveIt!

Author: glennfernandes_80780
Content:
Claude Sub Agents: The Evolution of AI Workflows

Core Concept
Claude Sub Agents are to System Prompts what Cursor Rules are for AI-generated code guardrails.
Simple analogy:
Cursor Rules managed code behavior (Global ‚Üí Project scope)
Claude Sub Agents manage conversation behavior (User ‚Üí Project scope)
Chained Sub Agent Orchestration
Think restaurant kitchen brigade system:
Head Chef (orchestrator) coordinates the entire meal
Station Chefs (specialized sub agents) handle specific tasks:
Garde manger (data preparation)
Saucier (analysis and reasoning)
Pastry chef (final formatting/presentation)
Each chef passes work to the next station. The head chef ensures proper sequencing, quality control, and final output meets requirements.
The magic: Specialization + Coordination = complex outputs no single agent could produce alone.
Claude Code Hooks
Just as IDE extensions hook into specific coding moments (file save, build, debug), Claude Code Hooks inject AI assistance at precise development lifecycle points.
Instead of copying/pasting system prompts or re-explaining needs, you simply invoke the appropriate Sub Agent that already "knows" your context.
Result: Persistent, reusable system prompts that eliminate repetitive setup and ensure consistent AI behavior.
The Evolution Path
Problem ‚Üí Solution ‚Üí MCP (Tools)
Your meta-agent becomes self-improving by:
Recognizing repetitive work patterns
Auto-spawning new sub-agents for those patterns
Continuously refining your agent ecosystem
Evolution: Manual prompts ‚Üí Sub Agents ‚Üí Code Hooks ‚Üí Meta-Agents that build themselves
This creates an exponentially scaling AI workforce that adapts and grows with your needs.
Next Level: Community Building
üî• Let's community build the Firebrand 10-minute sprint Multi Agent orchestrator!
Time to level up from prompts to self-building agent ecosystems.
"Let your agents build your agents" - Watch this Meta-Agent video to learn more https://youtu.be/7B2HJr0Y68g?feature=shared

Author: glennfernandes_80780
Content:
**Here is an excellent example of a chained sub agent orchestration workflow for Ignition University Module Creation**

**Is This a Good Use Case?** YES ‚úì
- This is an excellent use case for chained sub agent orchestration because it involves multiple distinct, sequential tasks that require specialized expertise and can be automated through a logical workflow.

**Orchestration Chain Architecture
Agent 1:** **Documentation Parser**
**Input:** Ignition 8.3 system documentation
**Task:** Extract features, APIs, and workflow requirements
**Output:** Structured feature maps and learning objectives
**Handoff:** Passes categorized content to Demo Agent

**Agent 2:** **Demo Automation Agent**
**Input:** Feature maps from Parser Agent
**Task:** Uses Playwright MCP to explore Ignition Gateway
**Output:** Recorded interactions, screenshots, and workflow captures
**Handoff:** Passes demo assets to Content Generator

**Agent 3:** **Content Generation Agent**
**Input:** Demo assets and structured feature data
**Task:** Creates step-by-step tutorials and educational materials
**Output:** Draft training modules with embedded demos
**Handoff:** Passes content to QA Agent

**Agent 4:** **Quality Assurance Agent**
**Input:** Draft training modules
**Task:** Validates accuracy, checks completeness, ensures consistency
**Output:** Polished Ignition University modules
**Handoff:** Final deliverable ready for deployment

Author: glennfernandes_80780
Content:
**Why Chaining Works Here**
**Sequential Dependencies**
- Documentation must be parsed before demos can be created
- Demos must be captured before educational content can be written
- Content must be generated before quality assurance can occur

**Specialized Expertise**
- Each agent optimized for its specific task type
- Parallel processing where possible (multiple feature demos simultaneously)
- Error isolation - failures in one stage don't crash entire pipeline

**Enhanced Workflow Benefits**
**Your Existing Agent as Orchestrator**
- Main Agent coordinates the entire chain
- Manages handoffs between specialized sub-agents
- Handles error recovery and retry logic
- Monitors progress across all stages

**Environment Switching Demo Chain**
- **Config Parser** ‚Üí Identifies Dev/Prod/Test differences
- **Environment Demo Agent** ‚Üí Records switching procedures
- **Tutorial Generator** ‚Üí Creates environment management guides
- **Validation Agent** ‚Üí Tests switching procedures

**Key Advantages**
- Fault tolerance through isolated agent responsibilities
- Scalability - can run multiple chains for different modules simultaneously
- Maintainability - easy to update individual agents without affecting others
- Quality control - dedicated QA agent ensures high standards

**Bottom Line:** This is a perfect chained orchestration use case that leverages your existing Claude Code Document Agent as the conductor for a specialized pipeline of content creation sub-agents.

Author: jcthibaudet
Content:
We have been working with a lot of system integrators recently to implement our digital strategy and I can see that it's expensive and it's not moving fast enough. All the time we have to rely on developers who are sick, on vacations, busy with another customer, having technical difficulties, don't understand what's asked... Development costs are through the roof and we are getting further behind schedule every week.
We are an Ignition shop and have to rely on a handful of developers who can do Ignition. Can't use AI to do the coding in Ignition (yet) üôÅ 
Inspired by  Walker and other building software with AI, for our Enterprise layer (AWS) I'm thinking to get rid of ignition and build everything from AI. With multitude of languages available I'm curious to know what would be a good AI friendly AWS stack. Our IT currently uses Amazon Q on bedrock, not 100% sure what that means yet but they have access to AI agents from there.
I have spent 5h this weekend playing with VSCode and AI agent doing a project in Django and this look promising, it's definitely not perfect and requires a LOT of supervision and step by step. It's not troubles free but I can see how quickly we could build all the apps we need.

Author: _dyland
Content: If you don't have the staff and expertise in house to build and maintain on top of a platform like Ignition, what level of staffing do you have to build, deploy, manage, and maintain custom code built in house? I love the thought of getting away from a reliance on integrators but this sounds a bit drastic?

Author: jcthibaudet
Content:
We have a small team of ignition developers for support and small projects. We are using Integrators to build the bulk of our systems like MES / eForms / dashboards.. 
I'm considering our current knowledge that's why I picked Django to be a python based system but you are right with this new architecture it will create a knowledge gap that we will need to address. Also we have a huge IT team and I'm leading toward aligning more with their technology stack as they will be able to help (maybe! :D). I'm also leaning using more IT based contractors so the pool of developers is much higher

Ignition is about as easy as it gets for a platform that requires coding.  If you're not able to build functionality in house I fail to see how another code based platform would be different.  Maybe I'm missing something.  

I built our basic MES in Ignition, relying a lot on vibe coding to learn the basics.  What was more important than learning programming, was learning about ISA-95.  I'm sure it's still filled with technical debt, but it's been a good learning experience.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Gilad is spot on. Most QMS are document control systems or like audit project management. For many industries, quality is paper and they don't know any other way so they unfortunately adopt a literal electronic equivalent of the process in software.

It's tough. There are not a lot of good options. I think most manufacturers are probably best seeing what they can lean on in their ERP or PLM suite to do and then try to extend that in a flexible application platforms (e.g., Tulip). The problem with these suites is the UX is usually poor for line-of-business users and there are gaps, but the backend master data can be useful.

Hexagon has a sprawling portfolio. They did buy QDAS and ETQ Reliance. Apparently, there is some web-based version of QDAS for SPC that doesn't look like WindowsXP era software. ETQ has a modern interface and they've done some integration with QDAS and the metrology products like PC-DMIS.

If you're a Salesforce shop, I might look into Propel PLM. They have some quality management stuff and it might be more extensible running on the SFDC platform.

I would talk with FactBird about their product aspirations. They're a lightweight OEE solution with some basic process control functionality. They have both small and big customers that speak highly of them. I'm curious what they would build given the opportunity.

I really liked Plex's approach. The routing, part specs, BOMs, FMEA, control plans, SPC, etc integrate nicely. It really "operationalizes" quality from receiving to production to shipping and it has APIs to tie into automation. Most of the functionality was built for and funded by automotive customers in the US. It audits well for ISO 9001, IATF 16949, VDA 6.3, MMOG/LE. I increasingly can't recommend Plex because they're too slow with enhancements, customer satisfaction issues, and Rockwell's reputation with software. I don't know if they would still sell it as a point solution with just the relevant quality modules.
